' : When Inspector (Insp) Rizduan Moktar and SC/SGT Muhammad Syahid Bin Faries received an alert about a woman in distress at Changi Beach, they knew they had to act fast. Drawing on his 24 years of experience, Insp Rizduan's instincts told him something wasn't right when they spotted a lone figure by the shore. The Changi NPC Ground Response Force officers called out to the woman, but their calls went unheeded. Then, she turned into the mounting waves.Without hesitation, both officers plunged into the choppy waters after her. Fighting against strong currents and weighted down by their uniforms, they pushed forward with a single mission - to bring her back safely.Equipment can be replaced. Lives cannot, says Insp Rizduan, who now mentors younger officers like SC/SGT Syahid at Changi NPC. For the 24-year-old PNSF officer who enlisted in October 2023, this incident proved that real-life situations demand more than just training - they require courage, quick thinking, and unwavering determination.This is the story of two officers, separated by decades of experience but united by their commitment to protect and serve. Written by: Domnic DassPhotos by: Naveen RajPNS50 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: Having served in the Singapore Police Force for 31 years since 1994, Senior Assistant Commissioner of Police (SAC) David Scott Arul, currently Commander of Training Command (TraCom), will hand over leadership to his successor this July upon his retirement. Throughout his time in SPF, he served in various units such as Tanglin Division, the Manpower Department, Operations, and was the Commander of the Special Operations Command (SOC) during pivotal moments like the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit. Presently, he is focused on developing the next generation of regular police officers and Police National Servicemen in his current and final capacity as Commander TraCom."Policing is about managing human interactions," SAC Scott reflects, sharing how policing has evolved with technological advancements, yet at its core, remains about human connections. Under his leadership at TraCom, he has adapted training methods to meet challenges such as improved operational readiness.When asked about his favourite posting in SPF, SAC Scott highlighted that being Commander SOC was an opportunity he jumped at. He also shared how contributing to frontline policing and operational roles provided purposeful and valuable takeaways in his career. You enjoy the job because you make it enjoyable, he candidly shares, crediting his fulfilling career in SPF to supportive colleagues, his ability to find meaning in every role and an understanding family, which he endearingly labels his rock that he can always fall back on.To all aspiring police officers, SAC Scotts message is simple: "If being in the Force has crossed your mind, just do it." After all these years, he has learned that a career in policing offers something for everyone, one that rewards dedication with meaningful connections.Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia LimPhotos by Naveen Rajspfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ !]Happy Fathers Day to all fathers out there! Supt Gunalan Govindasamy is a police veteran who has served more than 29 years in the Force. His story inspired his daughter, Tharani Gunalan, to also join him in keeping Singapore safe. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

KPN TERIMA DARJAH UTAMA BAKTI CEMERLANG DARIPADA PRESIDEN REPUBLIK SINGAPURASingapura, 12 Jun 2025 Ketua Polis Negara (KPN), IG Tan Sri Razarudin Husain telah dikurniakan Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang (Distinguished Service Order) oleh Presiden Republik Singapura, Tuan Yang Terutama Tharman Shanmugaratnam dalam satu istiadat rasmi yang berlangsung di The Istana, Orchard Road, semalam.Pengurniaan darjah itu merupakan antara penghormatan tertinggi Kerajaan Singapura kepada tokoh luar negara yang telah menunjukkan komitmen luar biasa, khususnya pencapaian cemerlang Tan Sri Razarudin dalam memperkukuh kerjasama keselamatan serta hubungan dua hala antara Polis Diraja Malaysia dan Pasukan Polis Singapura (SPF).Sempena lawatan rasmi itu, Tan Sri Razarudin turut mengadakan kunjungan hormat ke atas Pemangku Pesuruhjaya Polis Singapura, DCP Lian Ghim Hua di Ibu Pejabat SPF, New Phoenix Park.Beliau bersama isteri yang juga Pengerusi Persatuan Keluarga Polis Malaysia, Puan Sri Datuk Zainah Othman turut menghadiri Majlis Makan Malam Rasmi yang berlangsung di Senior Police Officers Mess. Majlis turut dihadiri para pegawai kanan SPF.Mengakhiri lawatan rasmi ke negara tersebut, Tan Sri Razarudin telah mengadakan kunjungan hormat ke atas Perdana Menteri Singapura, H.E. Mr. Lawrence Wong yang berlangsung di The Istana, Orchard Road, pagi tadi.Hadir sama, bekas Ketua Urus Setia KPN (Perhubungan Antarabangsa) Bukit Aman, pesara SAC Dato Pahlawan Suparamaniam Ramasamy dan ACP Perhubungan Antarabangsa, ACP Loh Pey Pey.Sumber gambar: Singapore Police Force

KPN TERIMA DARJAH UTAMA BAKTI CEMERLANG DARIPADA PRESIDEN REPUBLIK SINGAPURASingapura, 12 Jun 2025 Ketua Polis Negara (KPN), IG Tan Sri Razarudin Husain telah dikurniakan Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang (Distinguished Service Order) oleh Presiden Republik Singapura, Tuan Yang Terutama Tharman Shanmugaratnam dalam satu istiadat rasmi yang berlangsung di The Istana, Orchard Road, semalam.Pengurniaan darjah itu merupakan antara penghormatan tertinggi Kerajaan Singapura kepada tokoh luar negara yang telah menunjukkan komitmen luar biasa, khususnya pencapaian cemerlang Tan Sri Razarudin dalam memperkukuh kerjasama keselamatan serta hubungan dua hala antara Polis Diraja Malaysia dan Pasukan Polis Singapura (SPF).Sempena lawatan rasmi itu, Tan Sri Razarudin turut mengadakan kunjungan hormat ke atas Pemangku Pesuruhjaya Polis Singapura, DCP Lian Ghim Hua di Ibu Pejabat SPF, New Phoenix Park.Beliau bersama isteri yang juga Pengerusi Persatuan Keluarga Polis Malaysia, Puan Sri Datuk Zainah Othman turut menghadiri Majlis Makan Malam Rasmi yang berlangsung di Senior Police Officers Mess. Majlis turut dihadiri para pegawai kanan SPF.Mengakhiri lawatan rasmi ke negara tersebut, Tan Sri Razarudin telah mengadakan kunjungan hormat ke atas Perdana Menteri Singapura, H.E. Mr. Lawrence Wong yang berlangsung di The Istana, Orchard Road, pagi tadi.Hadir sama, bekas Ketua Urus Setia KPN (Perhubungan Antarabangsa) Bukit Aman, pesara SAC Dato Pahlawan Suparamaniam Ramasamy dan ACP Perhubungan Antarabangsa, ACP Loh Pey Pey.Sumber gambar: Singapore Police Force

[ ]2025 is a significant year for the SPF as we celebrate the 100th Anniversary of the SPF Band. At the Police Day Observance Ceremony, Minister Edwin Tong presented the 100th Anniversary Centennial Mace to Director of Music, Superintendent of Police (SUPT) Sulaiman Bin Abdul Wahab.The centennial mace was specially commissioned in commemoration of this significant milestone, and represents the unity, discipline and professionalism of the SPF Band. Its design features a silver lion head crown, five decorative ornamental crests showing historic police insignias, the State Crest, SPF chevrons and SPFs core values (Courage, Loyalty, Integrity, and Fairness) engraved at the top.Elegant and commanding, the Centennial Mace is not only a symbol of the Drum Majors authority but also a lasting emblem of the legacy, values, and spirit of the SPF Band as it proudly marches into its next century.happypoliceday singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50

[ ]Celebrated on 3 June every year, Police Day honours our pioneering officers and renews our commitment to the Forces mission. This years ceremony will see the SPF House of Colours flag party make its debut, celebrating both our shared heritage and distinctive unit identities.The SPF House of Colours embodies the spirit and heritage of each Police unit while maintaining the Forces unified presence. Introduced in 2015, the House of Colours system applies a consistent theme for unit logos while showcasing individual unit identities that have been built over many decades.Police National Service Inspector Nicholas Chong will be one of the flag bearers at this years ceremony.It's an honour to bear the Training Command Flag (TRACOM). It is our first home in the Force, where we forge our foundational values and learn what it means to be a Police officer and a leader. shared NSI Nicholas Chong.happypoliceday singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday PNS50

Maximillian embodies dual dedicationas a national swimmer and a full-time Police National Service (PNS) Officer in the Police Coast Guard (PCG). In PCG, he helps manage and coordinate crime and investigation operations. His NS journey has been filled with memorable milestones, like stepping up as emcee for the NS Change of Command ceremony just two weeks after joining PCG, a challenge that required quick adaptation and confidence. At the same time, taking on new responsibilities has pushed him to develop essential skills, reinforcing his ability to learn fast and stay detail-oriented.Beyond his police duties, Maximillian follows an intense training schedule. His day begins at 5am with swim training, followed by duty, then wraps up with strength training or another swim in the evening. As a multiple SEA Games gold medalist, Maximillian has represented Singapore on prestigious international stages, including the Asian Games, Commonwealth Games, Youth Olympic Games, and World Championships. He perseveres by embracing the mindset that nothing is impossible, setting ambitious goals that challenge him to continuously improve. When asked what keeps him going, Maximillian shared, My family and friends inspired me to do give my best in swimming and as a member of PCG. I always feel loved and supported by the people around me and this gives me the motivation to excel in the things I do, whether in sports, studies, NS or work.His journey proves that the discipline of sport and the duty of service go hand in hand. Maximillian continues to inspire with his dedication and resilience, like many other past and present PNS officers who had served and upheld SPFs mission for the past 50 years.Photos by Ong Lin Hui and singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50

Tech meets efficiency! Since 2021, the Automated Equipping System (AES) has been transforming how our officers gear up. Previously, the issuance and return of equipment were done manually, but this process is now automated. Officers can now withdraw and return items quickly and independently, saving valuable time and supercharging efficiency.And were just getting started! In 2024, we worked with to launch the Automated Armoury System (AAS) with smart lockers powered by RFID tech and two-factor authentication, allowing officers access to their armaments securely and on their own schedule. No more waiting just quick, seamless armament management.From manual processes often involving long queues to seconds of self-service, were revolutionising operational efficiency and ensuring our officers are always mission-ready! safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce spftech

() Youve probably seen them while taking the train or bus TransCom officers on patrol Theyre there to help keep the journey safe, secure and smooth, looking out for suspicious items and persons, and stepping in when needed. Its long hours on foot, but moments like helping someone in need make it worth it TransCom is also an NS-centric unit, with about 80% of its officers serving as Full-Time Police National Service (PNSF) officers. As we mark 50 years of Police National Service this year, were grateful for their continued commitment to keeping Singapore safe, every day. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday PNS50 transport

: , Meet ASP Molly, a dedicated police officer who has spent 33 years serving with unwavering commitment in the Singapore Police Force, in various units such as Commercial Crime Team, First Responder Training Unit and the Community Policing Unit. For her, it all started with a desire to break free from the desk-bound routine and embrace a career on the move. Over the years, she has been inspired by the diverse experiences, the adrenaline, and the ever-evolving nature of policing.ASP Molly has witnessed incredible changesfrom cutting-edge technology enhancing crime prevention and investigation, to the establishment of specialized counter-terrorism teams. One of her most meaningful contributions was being part of the team that set up the Tactical Training Unit in the Police Training Commandequipping officers across all ranks with the tactical skills needed to respond to public security threats.Outside of work, she finds motivation in reading, jogging, and spending time with her community. As a mother, ASP Molly is inspired by the quote, Mothers are not the ones who have never struggled. They are the ones that never give up, despite the struggles.Whether it's sharing wisdom with young minds or embracing fresh perspectives, she believes meaningful connections and continuous learning are key to staying relevant in an ever-changing world.Her personal mottolearn, unlearn, and relearn.Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim Photos by Ong Lin Hui and Cheyenne Ongspfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: Day and night, our officers worked tirelessly to ensure the safety and security of Election Meetings across Singapore throughout the campaigning period of the General Election (GE) 2025.Despite having their own full-time careers, many of our Police National Servicemen and Volunteer Special Constabulary officers have stepped forward to support the security deployments together with our regulars, civilian officers, and Police full-time National Servicemen. We are thankful for their immense dedication. We would also like to thank the members of the public for your understanding, patience and support on the ground all these while. The SPF remains steadfast in our mission to safeguard the GE2025.GE2025 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Behind the Scenes of GE2025: First In, Last Out - The Police Logistics DepartmentOfficers from the Police Logistics Department (PLD) provide critical and vital support to every major security deployment of the Singapore Police Force. They are often the first to be on site to put up the required security infrastructures, and last to leave to ensure that the venue is returned to its original state after a deployment. In between, they work tirelessly to coordinate between the units, HTX and contract partners to ensure all planned and the numerous additional support requests that surface during implementation are executed successfully. ASP Fabian Tan and his colleagues, ASP Kenneth Teo and Mr Norhalim Nordin and are some of the unsung heroes toiling behind the scenes, providing the essential logistical support to their frontline colleagues for GE2025. Their efforts ensure that operations can run smoothly and that officers can perform their duties effectively and efficiently. GE2025 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: The Police Elections Permit Office (PEPO) is an office within the Singapore Police Force, activated during election periods to process and manage permits for election-related activities.For Eunice, a first-time PEPO member and SPF Civilian Officer, the experience has been eye-opening! Its amazing to see how everything comes together in supporting the General Election everyones role is crucial in making the election process seamless.Eunice and her colleagues, Shinq Chyuan and Saravanan Baba from PEPO play an important role in upholding the orderliness of the electoral process. GE2025 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: SI Jeff joined the Force in 1997 and went on to serve as a Watch Team Patrol Officer in Geylang Police Division from 1998 to 2000. Subsequently, he went on to be a Ground Response Officer in Ang Mo Kio Police Division where he served as a first responder to ground emergencies.He is now an experienced frontline officer, leading as a Deputy Team Leader in Yishun NPC where he supports his Team Leader in overseeing the daily frontline operations. As the second-in-command of the team, he shapes the next generation of officers, fostering a culture of proactive policing and meaningful community engagement - to build trust and confidence in SPF.Beyond his core policing duties, SI Jeff also volunteers with other officers in Ang Mo Kio Police Division, giving back to the communities across Asia. After the devastating 2015 earthquake in Nepal, Hasta La Vista (members are made up of current and former police officers from Ang Mo Kio Police Division) purchased and delivered daily necessities for over 120 families who were affected by the disaster. After the trip to Nepal, Hasta La Vista continues to expand their volunteering efforts to orphanages and nursing homes. SI Jeff believes that being a police officer is more than just a job."It's about serving justice, protecting the vulnerable, and making a difference in our community every single day."Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim Photos by Ong Lin Hui and Cheyenne Ongspfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

SI Jeff believes that being a police officer is more than just a job."It's about serving justice, protecting the vulnerable, and making a difference in our community every single day."Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim Photos by Ong Lin Hui and Cheyenne Ongspfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: SI Jeff joined the Force in 1997 and went on to serve as a Watch Team Patrol Officer in Geylang Police Division from 1998 to 2000. Subsequently, he went on to be a Ground Response Officer in Ang Mo Kio Police Division where he served as a first responder to ground emergencies.He is now an experienced frontline officer, leading as a Deputy Team Leader in Yishun NPC where he supports his Team Leader in overseeing the daily frontline operations. As the second-in-command of the team, he shapes the next generation of officers, fostering a culture of proactive policing and meaningful community engagement - to build trust and confidence in SPF.Beyond his core policing duties, SI Jeff also volunteers with other officers in Ang Mo Kio Police Division, giving back to the communities across Asia. After the devastating 2015 earthquake in Nepal, Hasta La Vista (members are made up of current and former police officers from Ang Mo Kio Police Division) purchased and delivered daily necessities for over 120 families who were affected by the disaster. After the trip to Nepal, Hasta La Vista continues to expand their volunteering efforts to orphanages and nursing homes. SI Jeff believes that being a police officer is more than just a job."It's about serving justice, protecting the vulnerable, and making a difference in our community every single day."Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim Photos by Ong Lin Hui and Cheyenne Ongspfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

- The Singapore Police Force (SPF) conducted a counter-terrorism and emergency preparedness exercise at the Singapore Sports Hub on 15 April 2025. The exercise was organised by the SPF, supported by the Singapore Civil Defence Force and the Singapore Armed Forces, in close collaboration with Kallang Alive Sport Management. Ms Sun Xueling, Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs & Ministry of Social and Family Development, attended as the Guest-of-Honour. With more large-scale concerts and lifestyle events held at the Singapore Sports Hub, this exercise strengthens emergency preparedness against potential terror threats in diverse urban environments. In this exercise, the SPF demonstrated how post-blast investigations are conducted, where forensic examination of improvised explosive devices (IED) fragments at a post-blast scene can provide useful investigative leads on the structure and construction of the IED. Every member of the community has a role to play in keeping Singapore safe against terrorism by remaining vigilant at all times. The communitys timely action can help prevent catastrophic outcomes, save lives and keep our home safe. For more information on how you can help keep our home safe from terrorism, please visit the Instagram or SGSecure website ( Photos by: SC Javier Tay

On 4th April 2025, we were honoured to host Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at Punggol Neighbourhood Police Centre and Punggol Fire Station During the visit, our officers showcased the latest operational capabilities. PM Wong witnessed hands-on demonstrations including SPFs Counter-Drone Capability and Next-generation Fast Response Car and SCDFs Smart Classroom with Virtual Reality and Extended Reality training systems, High-Performance Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation and the Electric Pump Ladder. PM also had engagements with our Home Team National Servicemen (NSmen), who are part of more than 50,000 operationally ready NSmen and Full-time National Servicemen. They have all played a crucial role in keeping Singapore safe and secure over the past decades. This year also marks 50 years of Police National Service for SPF.We thank PM Wong for taking the time to visit us! OneHomeTeam safegaurdingeveryday thelifesavingforce

The Police Heritage Centre (PHC) will be temporarily closed for renovations and upgrading works from 1 April 2025 to the second half of 2026. This temporary closure will enable us to enhance our facilities to create a more immersive and interactive experience for our visitors in time to come.While the PHC is undergoing a transformation, we invite you to embark on a digital journey through Singapore's policing history via a virtual tour to discover how the Singapore Police Force has contributed to the safety and security of Singapore over the past 200 years. The self-guided virtual tour offers:360 views of our heritage galleriesCompelling stories of courage and dedication from our police officersFascinating insights into historic cases that shaped SingaporeExperience our virtual tour at your own pace via the link in our bio!

() () () Commissioner of Police Hoong Wee Teck and AFP Commissioner Reece Kershaw APM have renewed the agreement to combat transnational crime and enhance police cooperation.Under the MoU, the SPF and AFP will continue to strengthen our cooperation and proud history of engagement across joint operations, information sharing and capability building to disrupt criminal activity.

International Partnerships in ActionThe Singapore Police Forces (SPF) Special Operations Group (SOG) hosted 19 ATLAS officers at the Home Team Tactical Centre (HTTC) between 11 and 13 March 2025, marking a significant milestone in international tactical unit collaboration. The ATLAS Network connects the European Unions Special Intervention Units, facilitating the exchange of experiences and best practices in counter-terrorism.During the forum, the ATLAS participants experienced HTTCs comprehensive training facilities through focused discussions and demonstrations on the latest counter-terrorism tactics. The theme of discussion centred on the use of technology in different domains such as breaching, low-light close quarter battle and the use of drones.Through international collaboration and learning, the SPF remains dedicated to elevating our officers tactical excellence.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday specialoperationsgroup ATLAS

: ASP Herman of Queenstown NPC followed the footsteps of his grandfather and uncle when he joined the force in 1994, continuing a proud family tradition of service. Growing up, he was inspired by the dedication and courage of police officers, and with the full support of his late parents, he successfully completed six months of training to become a full-fledged police officer. Today, that legacy lives on with his nephew recentlyjoining SPF,marking four generations of his family serving in the Force.One of his most unforgettable moments came in 2021, during a high-stakes manhunt for a murder suspect in Jurong East. A single drop of blood led him and his team into a pitch-dark forested area, where they finally caught the armed suspect lying in wait. It was a moment of reliefwe knew we had stopped further harm and ensured justice was served, he recalled.Having witnessed the evolution of SPF from the introduction of body-worn cameras to advancements like PolCams he appreciates how technology has strengthened frontline policing. When hes off duty, youll find ASP Herman cruising the open roads of Malaysia and Thailand on his motorbikea way to recharge and stay sharp for the hurdles ahead.Maintain the positive attitude and eagerness to learn new things. True to his words, ASP Herman approaches every challenge with enthusiasm and unwavering passion, always ready to learn and grow.For him, policing isnt just a jobits a lifelong commitment.Produced by Brenda Teo and Cheyenne Ong. Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Today, that legacy lives on with his nephew recentlyjoining SPF,marking four generations of his family serving in the Force.One of his most unforgettable moments came in 2021, during a high-stakes manhunt for a murder suspect in Jurong East. A single drop of blood led him and his team into a pitch-dark forested area, where they finally caught the armed suspect lying in wait. It was a moment of reliefwe knew we had stopped further harm and ensured justice was served, he recalled.Having witnessed the evolution of SPF from the introduction of body-worn cameras to advancements like PolCams he appreciates how technology has strengthened frontline policing. When hes off duty, youll find ASP Herman cruising the open roads of Malaysia and Thailand on his motorbikea way to recharge and stay sharp for the hurdles ahead.Maintain the positive attitude and eagerness to learn new things. True to his words, ASP Herman approaches every challenge with enthusiasm and unwavering passion, always ready to learn and grow.For him, policing isnt just a jobits a lifelong commitment.Produced by Brenda Teo and Cheyenne Ong. Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

, , , , / / On the morning of 3 February 2025, Sgt Farzana and SC/Sgt Aarav observed that there was black smoke coming from one of the units along Norris Road while conducting foot patrol.Quick action followed: Immediate response with fire extinguishers Backup from SCDF Nearby officers (ASP Gerald, Sgt Damien, Sgt Benjamin and SC/Cpl Armand) joined the effort to assist in managing the incident ~20 people safely evacuatedAs the fire intensified, our team prioritised public safety, managing the scene until SCDF arrived.As police officers, our job goes beyond law enforcement its about saving and protecting lives in every way possible. On that day, we did just that. We tried to contain the fire while evacuating people in the unit to prevent anyone from getting hurt. We are happy to do our part when the community needs us, and are glad that no one was injured during the incident. ASP Gerald safeguardingeveryday

: Greeting us with a bright smile, the Head Investigation of Traffic Police (TP) Supt Cindy New, warmly welcomed us into her office at the TP Headquarters before recounting her 30-year-long career with the Singapore Police Force.Having spent more than 25 years in the investigation fraternity including her previous role as the Head Investigation of Jurong Division, we wondered what drives her every day. As clich as it may sound, every case we handle is unique. Each accident scene presents a grim reality twisted metal, injured victims, and sometimes, lives lost. Our job is to fact-find and uncover what happened by reconstructing the events, viewing camera footages and speaking to witnesses. Not just to determine who is at fault, but also to understand if we can prevent such accidents from happening again.Beyond the technical investigations, the emotional toll on my investigation officers can be immense. They are often the ones who need to deliver the hardest news to families, telling them that their loved one isnt coming home. No amount of experience prepares you for that. Hence, I place great emphasis on the welfare and mental well-being of my officers to ensure they are well taken care of.It was clear that her care for her officers was not all talk as her office walls were adorned with named photographs of her officers, a testament to her commitment to their personal and professional growth.Adding on, Supt Cindy shared: Road safety isnt just about enforcing laws. Behaviour of the road users play a very important part. One moment of recklessness can change lives forever. So please drive responsibly, follow the laws and think about the lives around you.Before we left, we asked for her advice to young officers in the Force. Stay focused on our mission. Do your best in every task you are assigned to and take charge of your career by having regular talks with your supervisors to unleash your potential.Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim.Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

- "Exercise Heartbeat", a counter-terrorism and emergency preparedness exercise, was held at the Marsiling Mall Hawker Centre on 15 February 2025, simulating a terror attack at a heartland area by self-radicalised individuals.The exercise was organised by the Singapore Police Force (SPF), supported by the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF), and the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF)."Exercise Heartbeat" builds on the close collaboration between Home Team agencies and community partners to increase preparedness against terror attacks, in support of SGSecure and Exercise SG Ready. The exercise is a reminder that community partners should periodically review their security measures, familiarise themselves with and validate their contingency plans, to enhance their readiness to respond to an emergency. Every member of the community has a role to play in keeping Singapore safe against terrorism by remaining vigilant at all times.Anyone with information on suspicious persons or activities can contact the Internal Security Department at 1800-2626-473 or the Police at 999, SMS to 70999, or submit the information online at or report it via the SGSecure mobile application. The communitys timely action can help prevent catastrophic outcomes, save lives and keep our home safe. For more information on how you can contribute to our fight against terrorism, please visit the Instagram or SGSecure website ( : / /

Established in 1925, the Singapore Police Force (SPF) band was formed with a small group of 33 officers who had musical experience.By the 1970s, the SPF band had evolved into a professional musical unit, with specialised training for its members.Today, the band serves as a musical ambassador for the SPF, representing the Force at international music festivals and performing at national events and functions to foster strong police-community relations through music. One example would be the performance to the public at the Istana during the Istana Open House on 2 Feb 2025.Stay tuned for more information on the various performances!Photo 1 by Ministry of Digital Development and Informationbringingthebeattoyousince1925 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday IstanaOpenHouse

- , When I met Supt David Heng, 54, at SecCom, he shared highlights from his 36-year journey with SPF. Inspired by Hong Kong police dramas, he joined the Force in 1988, starting as a patrol officer before joining SecCom in 1991.One standout moment in his career was leading the escort for Kim Jong Un during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit, a high-stakes mission where a simple thank you left a lasting impression. The Chief of Security held my hands and thanked us for our efforts. That was when I knew we had truly done a good job.Supt David has seen SPF evolve with modern tech and equipment and advises younger officers: Expect the unexpected and ask what you can do for the organisation.Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim Photos: Naveen Raj, Cheyenne Ongspfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ , ! ] Through , a nonprofit organisation that grants wishes of children who are battling critical illnesses, we are honoured to be part of Elis wish journey. Eli, who has always wanted to be a police officer, suited up in his own mini police uniform, explored the equipment and vehicle, tried collecting forensic evidence and even joined our officers on neighbourhood patrol to share scam prevention tips with members of the public! His bravery and positivity are truly insipring. Wishing you all the happiness in the world, little officer Eli! MakeAWish SingaporePoliceForce DreamComeTrue Inspiration

The Singapore Police Force (SPF) held a graduation parade for 66 Regular Police Officers and 340 Full-Time Police National Service Officers from the 197th Intake on 13 January 2025. This parade signifies the completion of their Police Officer Basic Course at the Police Training Command.Mr Vikram Nair, Member of the Government Parliamentary Committee for Home Affairs & Law, graced the parade as the Reviewing Officer.During his speech, Mr Vikram Nair commended the overseas-based Full-Time Police National Service Officer graduands who dutifully returned to serve their National Service to protect and serve the nation. Together with regular officers, they underwent a tough and realistic training programme to instil confidence when deployed operationally. Mr Vikram Nair reiterated to the graduating cohort that they are entrusted with the heavy responsibility of their mission, which is to prevent, deter and detect crime to ensure a safe and secure Singapore. He congratulated the graduating officers on completing their basic training and encouraged them to take pride in performing their duties to safeguard Singapore every day.Mr Vikram Nair also thanked the parents and friends who were present for their unwavering support during the officers training journey.Congratulations and well done to the graduating cohort!

' ' [ ]The long-awaited day has finally arrived. After months of rigorous training, the trainees are ready to graduate as newly minted policemen. The graduation parade is more than a ceremony; it signifies their transformation from eager recruits to trained officers, ready to serve with pride and responsibility. As they march onto the parade square for the final time, the graduands recite the Police Pledge with conviction, surrounded by their family and loved ones. Each word reflects their solemn commitment to uphold the values of courage, loyalty, integrity and fairness, the bedrock of their service to Singapore. Having stepped into the Home Team Academy as aspiring youths, they now leave as protectors of our nation. With their training behind them, they are prepared to keep Singapore safe and secure every day, fulfilling their duties with honour and dedication. AhBoystoPolicemensingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

: , Meet Deputy Assistant Commissioner of Police (DAC) Wong Keng Hoe, Commander of the Central Police Division.Central Police Division covers Singapore's downtown core, encompassing residential estates such as Tanjong Pagar and Jalan Besar, as well as the Marina Bay area and the Central Business District. DAC Wong and his team will be in charge of the safety and security of Marina Bay Countdown 2025. "It is an iconic event that draws very large crowds every year.This year, we will be using more live cameras, UAVs, and illuminated signages to help in the crowd control. These have proven to be effective for us, especially in sense-making. I have also been running through the plans with the team, conducting exercises, and walking around the Marina Bay area to watch out for any changes to the terrain.Personally, I am excited to be part of this countdown deployment. It is a very special feeling to be counting down the new year with my fellow officers and the rest of Singapore.If you intend to visit the Marina Bay area for Countdown, please utilise the Crowd portal for real-time information on crowd levels, closure areas, and nearest transport nodes. Please also be vigilant of your surroundings and report any suspicious activity to the Police. says DAC Wong.Let's work together to make the Countdown experience an enjoyable one for all! SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ ]On 28 December 2024 at about 1.04pm, the Police were informed that two cyclists on their mountain bikes had lost their way in the Mandai forested area. Officers from Ang Mo Kio Division, Jurong Division and Gurkha Contingent were swiftly deployed to locate the missing cyclists. The missing cyclists were subsequently located and brought to safety by the Police at about 4:10pm. They were unhurt.The public is advised to stay on designated trails while cycling or trekking for their own safety.

: ()Meet SSSgt Fiona (not her real name), an STS officer who specialises in dealing with high-risk seaborne incidents, such as counter-terrorism operations. Together with her team of officers from the Police Coast Guard, they are tasked with ensuring the safety and security of Singapore's territorial waters.Having been in the STS for close to nine years, SSSgt Fiona is also a trained medical officerwho iscapable in managing mass casualty situations and treating injuries such as gunshot wounds. These skills enable her to provide prompt medical care to the wounded before professional medical help arrives.As an officer in a unit that prides itself on physical and tactical adeptness, officers like SSSgt Fiona are required to be trained in various tactical skills, to maintain a high level of fitness, and also be kept abreast of threats around the world."The situation on the ground is always dynamic and challenges can be unpredictable. But with the skills, knowledge, experience, and the great bunch of teammates that I have, I am confident that we can overcome any challenges and threats that may come our way.I must also give credit to the cooling breeze that we feel on our boats out at sea that takes away any stress and keeps us refreshed! (laughs)" - SSSgt FionaSPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ ]A counter-terrorism and emergency preparedness exercise (Exercise Heartbeat) was held at ITE College West on 18 November 2024. The exercise, led by the Police and supported by the SCDF, highlights the collaboration between the Home Team and the community to enhance community preparedness in dealing with terror attacks under the SGSecure movement.Assoc Prof Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development, was the Guest-of-Honour at the event. Everyone has a role in building our resilience against terror attacks, and maintaining vigilance at workplaces, neighbourhoods and places where we live, work and play. Acting quickly is vital, as the impact of a terror attack extends beyond the immediate point of attack. These actions can save lives and help our nation recover quickly from a crisis.For more information, visit by: SC Javier Tay

[ ]Physical training is an essential part of life at the Police Training Command, where future officers build the resilience and strength required for their exciting and challenging roles ahead. Trainees take on rigorous fitness drills, combat tactics training and weapon handling training amongst many others, to ensure that they competent in carrying out their duties as police officers. But its more than just physical training; its about cultivating discipline, grit, and teamwork, ensuring each officer is ready to serve and safeguard our community every day. AhBoysToPolicemensingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Dato Paduka Seri Haji Mohammad Irwan Bin Haji Hambali, Commissioner of Police of the Royal Brunei Police Force, was conferred the Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang (Distinguished Service Order) by President Tharman Shanmugaratnam on 15 October 2024 at the Istana.CP Dato Mohammad Irwan was appointed Commissioner of Police of Royal Brunei Police Force on 22 June 2019. Under his leadership, the bilateral relationship between the Royal Brunei Police Force and the Singapore Police Force was strengthened, underpinnedby close cooperation in capacity and capability building. CP Dato Mohammad Irwan strongly supported mutual training exchanges between the two Police forces which helped hone the specialised skillsets of officers.This close cooperation reflects CP Dato Mohammad Irwans strong commitment to advancing bilateral ties between Brunei and Singapore and in turn, enhance the safety and security of both nations.The Singapore Police Force and Royal Brunei Police Force enjoy a longstanding partnership built on mutual trust and unwavering commitment to fighting crime. We will continue to strengthen this partnership and leverage our combined expertise to better safeguard our nations, said Commissioner of Police Hoong Wee Teck.During his stay in Singapore, CP Dato Mohammad Irwan made courtesy calls on Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong and Commissioner of Police Hoong Wee Teck.

, , , On the morning of 16 September 2024, SI Aniq and SGT Fayyaz from Rochor NPC were at Block 7 North Bridge Road when they noticed a strong burning smell in the vicinity. SI Aniq conducted a visual scan from the exterior of the block and saw thick smoke emanating from a units kitchen window. Aniq alerted the SCDF immediately and called for back-up whilst running up the stairs to the unit to attend to the incident.Upon reaching the affected level, the common corridor was already engulfed in thick black smoke. Braving the smoke, Aniq and Fayyaz crouched down and rushed towards the unit. There, they saw an elderly man standing at the main gate, clutching his pants and t-shirt. He was trying to exit the unit, but the gate was locked and he was unsure where the key was.While SI Aniq and SGT Fayyaz were attempting to calm the man down and jog his memory on where the key was kept, SGT Tong and SC Armand arrived and assisted to quickly evacuate occupants of the neighbouring units to safety.During the engagement, the man suddenly threw two pairs of pants and a shirt out of the unit. Wasting no time, SGT Fayyaz searched the pants for the key and in a slightly burnt pants pocket, SGT Fayyaz found it. Officers quickly opened the gate and brought the man to safety. By this time, the black smoke had thickened and started to irritate the eyes of the officers. In spite of that, two officers rushed into the unit and put out the fire with an extinguisher. The man was subsequently conveyed to hospital for treatment of his burn injuries. At that moment, all we wanted to do is to save the man and evacuate his neighbours to safety. Looking back, our safety were likely at risk too because the smoke was getting thicker by the minute. But I am glad everyone was safe, including the man. If I had a choice, I would still have stuck with my decision to stay put to save a life, said SI Aniq.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

, , , On the morning of 16 September 2024, SI Aniq and SGT Fayyaz from Rochor NPC were at Block 7 North Bridge Road when they noticed a strong burning smell in the vicinity. SI Aniq conducted a visual scan from the exterior of the block and saw thick smoke emanating from a units kitchen window. Aniq alerted the SCDF immediately and called for back-up whilst running up the stairs to the unit to attend to the incident.Upon reaching the affected level, the common corridor was already engulfed in thick black smoke. Braving the smoke, Aniq and Fayyaz crouched down and rushed towards the unit. There, they saw an elderly man standing at the main gate, clutching his pants and t-shirt. He was trying to exit the unit, but the gate was locked and he was unsure where the key was.While SI Aniq and SGT Fayyaz were attempting to calm the man down and jog his memory on where the key was kept, SGT Tong and SC Armand arrived and assisted to quickly evacuate occupants of the neighbouring units to safety.During the engagement, the man suddenly threw two pairs of pants and a shirt out of the unit. Wasting no time, SGT Fayyaz searched the pants for the key and in a slightly burnt pants pocket, SGT Fayyaz found it. Officers quickly opened the gate and brought the man to safety. By this time, the black smoke had thickened and started to irritate the eyes of the officers. In spite of that, two officers rushed into the unit and put out the fire with an extinguisher. The man was subsequently conveyed to hospital for treatment of his burn injuries. At that moment, all we wanted to do is to save the man and evacuate his neighbours to safety. Looking back, our safety were likely at risk too because the smoke was getting thicker by the minute. But I am glad everyone was safe, including the man. If I had a choice, I would still have stuck with my decision to stay put to save a life, said SI Aniq.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: Meet Station Inspector (SI) Shaoxiong, an Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV) pilot in the Aerial Response Team (ART). As a UAV pilot in the ART, SI Shaoxiong and his fellow UAV pilots harness their UAV-piloting skills to assist and support in Police operations. Armed with their trusty UAVs that are equipped with thermal imaging capabilities, SI Shaoxiong and his colleagues pilot their UAVs to fly high above to provide ground commanders with an aerial situational picture, enhancing the Polices sense-making capabilities and response on the ground. Police operations that SI Shaoxiong and his colleagues are deployed to can vary from major security events such as the New Year Countdown celebrations at Marina Bay to enforcement operations, and even search and rescue operations.As a UAV pilot, staying attentive to ground challenges is crucial. Quick thinking and being decisive are also essential traits when navigating through unforeseen circumstances. UAV pilots undergo continuous and rigorous training regularly to ensure that they are well prepared for various scenarios they may encounter during operations.As a UAV pilot in the ART, my role is to support ground operations by providing real-time insights from high above. Every flight provides useful information to our officers on ground to make better decisions and to respond swiftly and decisively. I am glad to be able to play a meaningful role in helping to ensure mission success in every operation we carry out, says SI Shaoxiong. SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

This is where their journey to becoming a police officer begins, as they bid goodbye to their families and say hello to their newfound squadmates AhBoysToPoliceMensingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

: ()Meet ASP Jannah Wong, a Team Leader (TL) in Tanglin Divisions ERT. As an ERT TL, her role is to lead her team in serving as the first wave of response to public security incidents, armed attacks and firearm incidents. Owing to the nature of the incidents the ERT responds to, ERT officers like ASP Jannah undergo regular physical and tactical training to keep up with the standards required of them. On top of that, ASP Jannah cultivates and instils the mindset of anticipating the unexpected in her team, acknowledging that training ones mental resilience is equally as important as physical training. This ensures that they are well-prepared for a wide range of incidents which they may encounter on the ground. Challenging, fulfilling and fun. These are 3 words I would use to describe my experience in the ERT. With the nature of the job, there is no doubt that it can get challenging. Despite that, it is truly fulfilling to see my team contribute to public safety by addressing various incidents with the skills we have acquired. The rigorous regimen of physical and tactical training that being in the ERT entails is also enjoyable, as I always had a passion for activities that involve discipline and drive. Being able to train alongside officers who share the same interest and passion as I do makes it even more enjoyable and drives my passion even more!Have I also mentioned that the ERT has also provided me with another aspect of fun too? Perhaps you would understand what I mean if you spot me performing at this years National Day Parade! (laughs) - ASP JannahKeep your eyes peeled for ASP Jannahs spectacular showcase of the ERTs capabilities in the upcoming National Day Parade!SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) Jeremy Png is a Course Manager at the Police Training Command. As a course manager, DSP Jeremy trains and nurtures the next generation of police officers and leaders, imparting them with the essential skills, knowledge, and values for them to succeed as competent officers.In the little pockets of time DSP Jeremy has while on leave or on weekends, he dresses up as a clown to tell stories and perform magic tricks to children warded in the hospital to distract them from the hospital procedures and help them deal with the range of emotions they may experience. He also visits nursing homes to entertain and interact with the residents, helping to keep their spirits high.I have always had a strong passion for helping people, especially the weak and the vulnerable. That is why I became a police officer in 1991 and why I decided to volunteer. There are people amongst us going through tough times and I hope my presence, even if momentarily, can help distract them from their pain, discomfort or problems.There is one line within the Police Pledge which says, we pledge to serve our community and our country and I think this line resonates with me. I am happy to be able to make small differences to the lives of others through volunteering, while continuing to make meaningful contributions to our country in my job as a police officer. Read more about DSP Jeremys volunteering journey via the link in our bio.Photos 3 & 4 credit: PSD Challenge

As a course manager, DSP Jeremy trains and nurtures the next generation of police officers and leaders, imparting them with the essential skills, knowledge, and values for them to succeed as competent officers.In the little pockets of time DSP Jeremy has while on leave or on weekends, he dresses up as a clown to tell stories and perform magic tricks to children warded in the hospital to distract them from the hospital procedures and help them deal with the range of emotions they may experience. He also visits nursing homes to entertain and interact with the residents, helping to keep their spirits high.I have always had a strong passion for helping people, especially the weak and the vulnerable. That is why I became a police officer in 1991 and why I decided to volunteer. There are people amongst us going through tough times and I hope my presence, even if momentarily, can help distract them from their pain, discomfort or problems.There is one line within the Police Pledge which says, we pledge to serve our community and our country and I think this line resonates with me. I am happy to be able to make small differences to the lives of others through volunteering, while continuing to make meaningful contributions to our country in my job as a police officer. Read more about DSP Jeremys volunteering journey via the link in our bio.Photos 3 & 4 credit: PSD Challenge

The SPF Band represented Singapore on a global stage at the Basel Tattoo in Switzerland. Being the only band from Asia in attendance this year, the SPF Combined Band, comprising the SPF Band, the Women Police Pipes and Drums as well as the Gurkha Contingent Pipes and Drums Platoon showcased Singaporean culture to the spectators of the Basel tattoo. Titled the Tapestry of Temasek, the performance led by Director of Music SUPT Sulaiman Abdul Wahab features traditional elements and dances from Indian, Malay, Eurasian and Chinese cultures including a lion dance segment performed entirely by SPF officers. Promoting the Singaporean culture on a global stage, the performances spread across 2 weeks have been met with praise and standing ovations from local and foreign crowds.The SPF Band also performed alongside musicians from across the world such as the Australian Army Band, the US Army Field Band and the Swiss Armed Forces Brass Band in combined segments that highlighted collaboration between countries from around the world.

: Meet SC/Sgt 2 Reanu Tarin Ali, one of the many Full-Time Police National Service (PNSF) officers serving in the Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) as a Group Leader (GL). Being a specialist unit with the mission of protecting Singapores public land transport system, TransCom officers like SC/Sgt 2 Reanu are the first to respond to incidents at MRT stations and bus interchanges. As a GL, SC/Sgt 2 Reanu leads a three-man team to conduct high visibility foot patrols at MRT stations and bus interchanges to deter and detect crime. He also engages commuters and public transport operators to disseminate and share anti-crime advisories. Additionally, he is responsible for the well-being and safety of his men under his charge. At times, I find it challenging to be a GL in a NS-centric unit since I have to lead my peers. Nevertheless, I see value in my role as I play a part to prevent, detect and deter crime from being committed within Singapores public land transport system. Beyond this, being a GL also provides me with a unique opportunity to hone my leadership skills during my time in National Service. SC/Sgt 2 Reanu SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: ()Meet ASP Candy, the first female officer who has successfully completed the Police Tactical Course in the Special Operations Command!The Police Tactical Course was designed to be mentally and physically challenging to help hone trainees skills and tactics in dealing with public order and public security threats. It is one of the more physically gruelling courses, even for male officers.As women, our physical build is naturally different from the men. Despite how others may view it as an additional hurdle I had to overcome, I harnessed it as a strength instead, allowing it to push me to discover new ways to navigate these challenges. Our body and mind are capable of limitless potential and if you are determined to do something, you can achieve it. And yes, I certainly do hope to see more female PTU officers joining me in the years to come! (laughs) ASP CandySPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

() , Clementi Police Division has clinched the Best Land Division award three times in a row at the Police Day Parade held at the Home Team Academy on 3 June 2024.One officer who has witnessed it all is veteran Supt Lim Sin Kim, Head Logistics and Finance in Clementi Police Division. This is not surprising, given that he has spent more than 25 years in the Division, serving 10 different commanders.Supt Lim joined the Singapore Police Force (SPF) as a Police Constable in February 1985 and began his career as a patrol team officer. He also had postings in the investigation and operation domains in his 39 years with the SPF. He has risen through the ranks over the years, and is now a Superintendent of Police, responsible for managing the finance and logistics aspects in the Division.When I first joined the SPF in the 1980s, the patrol car was pretty much just a normal car with a police logo on it. On the interior, it looks like any other car on the road. Today, our next-generation fast response car integrates technology and functional design, which greatly improves our officers operational effectiveness and safety at the frontline.Also gone were the days where we need to do photo-fit to get a rough idea of how our suspects look like! Today, our police cameras are able to provide useful leads quickly to help us solve cases.And of course, as the society progresses, actions by the police on the ground will sometimes get scrutinised by the public. It is a challenge that we have to deal with, and I always share with my officers that as long as we remain professional and stay true to our core values in every case we handle, we will be fine.(Continued in comments)

[ ]The Singapore Police Force (SPF) held the Police Day Parade 2024 on 3 June 2024 at the Home Team Academy. Mr Teo Chee Hean, Senior Minister (SM) and Coordinating Minister for National Security, was the Guest of Honour at the parade. Commemorated annually on 3 June since 1971, Police Day celebrates the SPFs achievements, recognises the contributions of past and present officers, and brings officers together to renew our pledge to serve Singapore and to carry out our duties with courage, loyalty, integrity, and fairness.Clementi Police Division was awarded the Best Land Division award while Airport Police Division was awarded the Best NS Operationally Ready Unit. Both units clinched the top honours for three consecutive years.The SPF Combined Band enthralled the audience with a performance which showcased a display of Singapores rich multiculturalism through the blend of military music, Scottish bagpipes, and ethnic percussions. The parade drew to a spectacular close as the mobile column, featuring a line-up of 35 police vehicles, made its way through the parade square.It was a befitting end to the parade where we reaffirmed our commitment to keep Singapore safe and secure every day Read more on Police Life (link in bio)happypoliceday singaporepoliceforcesaferneighbourhoodsinsg

The parade drew to a spectacular close as the mobile column, featuring a line-up of 35 police vehicles, made its way through the parade square.It was a befitting end to the parade where we reaffirmed our commitment to keep Singapore safe and secure every day Read more on Police Life (link in bio)happypoliceday singaporepoliceforcesaferneighbourhoodsinsg

: - Im INSP Kelvyn Owen and a trainer with the Police K-9 Unit. This is my 20th year in the unit, where I started off as an officer in the frontline before taking on my current role as a trainer.As a trainer, I help train the K-9 dogs and equip them with the skills and capabilities to conduct patrols; to assist in search and rescue operations; and to assist in the detection of drugs, explosives and firearms during police operations.The bond between the K-9 dog and its handler is crucial too. During my training sessions, I would often share tips with new handlers on how to work effectively with their dogs by understanding their behaviours and signals.As a trainer, one of the biggest challenges is to learn how to adapt to the different learning styles of the various dogs. I recalled it was quite challenging training Jack (as pictured)! He wasnt really attentive in the beginning and I had to try out various training methodologies to keep him engaged for him to acquire the necessary skills. I am happy to share that Jack is now a capable and well-trained Police Patrol Dog with the K-9! (laughs)I am grateful for the opportunity to train and work with like-minded canine-loving officers in our closely knitted K-9 Unit to contribute to the safety and security of Singapore! SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ ]The Police Workplan Seminar 2024 was held on 24 May 2024 at the Singapore University of Technology and Design. Deputy Prime Minster Heng Swee Keat was the Guest-of-Honour. He delivered the keynote speech and launched the Cyber Guardians on Watch and Cyber Crime Prevention Ambassadors schemes.The Cyber Guardians on Watch encourages individuals from all walks of life to play a role in safeguarding our cyberspace. Members of the scheme receive updates on the latest cybercrimes and scams, empowering them to spread awareness among their friends and loved ones. They serve as the eyes and ears of the SPF in the digital realm, reporting any suspicious activities.The Cyber Crime Prevention Ambassadors programme provides an avenue for members of the community who want to be more involved and take on an even more proactive role to safeguard our cyberspace. These ambassadors will undergo specialised training on emerging cybercrime trends and prevention measures, enabling them to educate the public through roadshows and community events.Initiatives to enhance cybercrime and scams-fighting capabilities and leverage Artificial Intelligence for new frontiers in policing were also unveiled at the seminar.The SPF constantly innovates and transforms itself to be a cyber-ready Police Force for the nation. Combatting cybercrimes, including scams, is a whole-of-society effort. Through ongoing collaboration with communities and stakeholders, the SPF remains dedicated to its mission of ensuring a safer Singapore for all.

" Formed in October 1945, the Radio Division had its origins as the Gangs and Radio Sub-Branch in the Criminal Investigations Department. The use of radio communication allowed the Police to respond much more quickly to the rising incidence of armed robbery across Singapore after World War II.In 1947, the Police hotline 999 was introduced for the public to call for Police assistance in the case of emergencies. The call would be directly linked to the Radio Control Room. Strategically located at Eu Tong Sen Street, the Police could effectively dispatch its radio cars for island wide operations.By 1951, there were more than 8,000 999 calls received. By the mid-1950s, the Radio Division operated 13 radio networks and a fleet of 60 patrol cars. Over the last 3 years, the Police Operations Command Centre (POCC) which was launched in 2015, has received an average of more than 1.6 million calls per year. Officers at the POCC and Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) Operations Centre are also now able to initiate video streaming if needed during an emergency call.This new capability jointly developed by SPF, SCDF, and HTX in collaboration with ST Engineering will aid officers in their situational assessment and decision-making to facilitate the necessary emergency response.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: ()Im SI Sritharan and Im a TP officer.My primary responsibilities as a TP officer are to engage and educate road users on good road safety habits and behaviour, and to enforce traffic laws.One of the challenges I faced as a TP officer is dealing with difficult road users. Sometimes, road users can be hostile when they are stopped by us. They may think that they did not commit any traffic violation and would be defensive as they may face a penalty for their driving behaviours. However, this does not deter us from educating them to be responsible road users. It spurs me on to carry out my duties professionally knowing that my work helps everyone return home safely to their loved ones. Also, if you ever get stopped by us while using the roads responsibly, do not be alarmed! You might find yourself pleasantly surprised with a reward as a part of the ongoing Reward the Sensible Motorists campaign! Use our roads safely and responsibly everyone! SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

- " " The 'sexual crime report' option has been implemented in the Integrated Queue Management System (IQMS) kiosk at Police stations to provide increased privacy and priority for victims of sexual crimes. Selecting this option at the IQMS kiosk triggers an alert at the counter terminal, which allows victims of sexual crimes to be attended to promptly and privately in an interview room, without having to reveal details of the case over the counter. This initiative strengthens Police's victim-centric approach in the management of sexual crime by enhancing the reporting procedures at the NPCs for victims of sexual crimes. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[- ]The Singapore Police Force (SPF) hosted a Dining-In on 17 April 2024 in honour of Prime Minister (PM) Lee Hsien Loong at the Senior Police Officers Mess. More than 100 attendees were present, including Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law; Mr Aubeck Kam, Permanent Secretary Home Affairs Development & Social and Family Development; and Mr Hoong Wee Teck, Commissioner of Police.The SPF hosted PM Lee at the same venue 10 years ago. At that Dining-In in 2014, PM Lee spoke about two areas which he said the SPF must never neglect. First, to maintain the highest standards of integrity, commitment, and professionalism, so that the publics strong trust in the SPF can be sustained. Second, to continue to invest in technology, so that the SPF can keep up with the latest threats, and deal with them effectively.Today, the publics trust in the SPF remains high. The SPF has also invested heavily in technology, and developed new capabilities. From expanding Police camera coverage and analytics, and harnessing unmanned systems as well as countering threats from them, to the use of artificial intelligence to fight scams, the SPF has been pushing technological boundaries.This has enabled our lean Force to keep crime rates low, solve crime swiftly, and hence secure the trust and confidence of Singaporeans.The Parliamentary Motion to commemorate SPF200 in 2021 was a significant milestone for the SPF. We thank PM Lee and the Parliament of Singapore for recognising the SPF as a world-class agency and SPF officers contributions in safeguarding Singapore. The SPF would like to thank PM Lee for the trust and support that PM Lee has given to the SPF. The SPF will continue to strive for the highest level of operational excellence and professionalism by upholding our core values of Courage, Loyalty, Integrity, and Fairness.Read more on (link in bio)

[- ]The Singapore Police Force (SPF) hosted a Dining-In on 17 April 2024 in honour of Prime Minister (PM) Lee Hsien Loong at the Senior Police Officers Mess. More than 100 attendees were present, including Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law; Mr Aubeck Kam, Permanent Secretary Home Affairs Development & Social and Family Development; and Mr Hoong Wee Teck, Commissioner of Police.The SPF hosted PM Lee at the same venue 10 years ago. At that Dining-In in 2014, PM Lee spoke about two areas which he said the SPF must never neglect. First, to maintain the highest standards of integrity, commitment, and professionalism, so that the publics strong trust in the SPF can be sustained. Second, to continue to invest in technology, so that the SPF can keep up with the latest threats, and deal with them effectively.Today, the publics trust in the SPF remains high. The SPF has also invested heavily in technology, and developed new capabilities. From expanding Police camera coverage and analytics, and harnessing unmanned systems as well as countering threats from them, to the use of artificial intelligence to fight scams, the SPF has been pushing technological boundaries.This has enabled our lean Force to keep crime rates low, solve crime swiftly, and hence secure the trust and confidence of Singaporeans.The Parliamentary Motion to commemorate SPF200 in 2021 was a significant milestone for the SPF. We thank PM Lee and the Parliament of Singapore for recognising the SPF as a world-class agency and SPF officers contributions in safeguarding Singapore. The SPF would like to thank PM Lee for the trust and support that PM Lee has given to the SPF. The SPF will continue to strive for the highest level of operational excellence and professionalism by upholding our core values of Courage, Loyalty, Integrity, and Fairness.Read more on (link in bio)

- "" Step back in time to the launch of the Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) system in 1997, pioneered by Queenstown Neighbourhood Centre. The NPCs served as one-stop police centres and brought wider range of police services to the community. It allowed the Police to work in, with and through the community via the community safety and security programmes.In 2012, the Community Policing System was introduced to further strengthen the partnership with the community. The NPCs were restructured to include the Community Policing Unit and Crime Strike Force to encourage joint ownership and responsibility with the community countering terrorism and fighting crime. Technology was harnessed as a force multiplier and the Neighbourhood Police Posts were enhanced to provide the community with round-the-clock access to automated services.We will continue to enhance police-community partnership to keep Singapore safe and secure every day.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Join us at The Star Vista, 13th April, this Saturday from 10am-8pm, in celebration of the 75 years of women in policing! This event commemorates the accomplishments and contributions of both past and present generations of female police officers. Come and join us for hands-on sessions at the weapon displays, and enjoy live performances by the Women Police Pipes & Drums and a special all-women combo band. Be sure to stay for the demonstrations by various units such as the Ground Response Force, Emergency Response Team, and the Security Command.Psst! Keep your eyes peeled for our exclusive collectibles too! See you there!

() On 26 October 2023, off-duty SI Alif Rashid spotted a boy in his primary school uniform loitering at a HDB void deck near a supermarket in Punggol in the late evening. As school dismissals are usually in the early afternoon, Alif sensed that something was amiss, and he decided to approach the boy. The boy shared that he had lost his way and could not find the way home.SI Alif noticed that the boy had a phone with him, but the battery was flat. He offered to charge his phone so that the boy could contact his family. In the meantime, he bought food and drinks for the boy as he did not have any food since early afternoon. After SI Alif successfully turned the boys phone on, he noticed that there were more than 5 missed calls from various numbers. Immediately, he contacted one of the numbers, which belonged to the boys grandfather.Over the phone, the boys grandfather told SI Alif that they had been looking for him for the past few hours and they were very worried. SI Alif then informed the boys grandfather that he is a police officer and that he approached the boy as he sensed that something was off. SI Alif waited with the boy until his family reunited with him at the void deck.After the incident, one of the boys family members wrote to the Police to compliment SI Alif, I dont know how to thank the officer.. He even buy food and offer care until my daughter came to fetch my grandson. I would like to recommend this officer for his good Samaritans deed..As a parent, I can understand how the boys family felt when they could not reach him for hours. I am happy to be able to do a small part to help to reunite the boy with his family, said SI Alif. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

From 1 April 2024, the Traffic Police (TP) will progressively and dynamically activate the speed enforcement function in Red Light Cameras (RLCs) island-wide to improve motorists behaviour. The RLCs are painted in orange and white and are accompanied by warning signs placed before the RLCs stating, Traffic Police Camera Zone, with the road speed limit sign above it.This activation is driven by an increase in the number of speeding-related fatal accidents year-on-year, and motorists speeding at locations where they think there is no enforcement. TP would like to urge motorists not to speed and to abide by traffic rules. TP will continue to take enforcement action against errant motorists. Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility!SingaporePoliceForce Safeguardingeveryday UseYourRoadSense

: () I'm SGT Lim Wee Ern, a GRF officer from Bukit Merah East Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC).As GRF officers, we respond to '999' calls and conduct patrols to prevent, deter and detect crime.On the ground, we face dynamic situations which sometimes can take a 180-degree turn within seconds for the better or for the worse. Thankfully, we undergo rigorous training regularly to equip ourselves to handle such situations professionally. Our top priority in such situations is always to ensure the safety of all parties involved, and if use of force is required, we will apply it proportionately to resolve the incident effectively and restore peace.I enjoy my job as a GRF officer. It gives me the opportunity to engage and interact with members of the public to find out how we can help improve the safety and security of the community, and it gives me a profound sense of accomplishment and satisfaction when I am able to assist someone in need of our help. SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

informed, stay safe! Police is a mobile app, with a focus on providing the latest Police news and crime prevention advisories.Its core functions include quick access to emergency functions, updated Police news and appeals, and Police e-services. Users can also obtain useful information on our community programmes and recruitment campaigns.Volunteers from the Citizens on Patrol (COP) scheme use the Citizens on Patrol Volunteer Module within the app to manage their volunteering activities, such as organising patrols and tracking patrol hours.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

The SPFs In-Situ Reaction Team (IRT) from the Protective Security Command is a specialized unit tasked with providing high-visibility police patrol and swift response to public security threats.They are highly trained and equipped with the necessary equipment and tactics to handle diverse situations.The IRT officers work closely with officers from other SPF units to maintain public safety and security in Singapore.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Did you know that the Singapore Police Force (SPF) Band is the oldest band in Singapore? Established in 1925, the SPF band boasts a rich heritage and is renowned for its wide repertoire of music ranging from popular favourites, big band, ethnic music of Southeast Asia to the more serious classical transcriptions. Besides encompassing a host of ensembles such as the SPF Big Band, Concert Band, Police Quintet, and the Brass Quintet, the band also has the distinction of being the only service band in Singapore that is complemented by bagpipes and drums, known as the Women Police Pipes & Drums. Earlier in February 2024, the SPF Band, together with Maestro Joost Chistiaan Flach from the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts treated the audience to a multi-sensory midday feast at the Home Team Academy! Catch the SPF Band in action this coming Saturday, 16 March 2024, 5.30pm at VivoCity Amphitheatre Level 3! All event proceeds will be donated to charity. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

" Located at Mount Pleasant, the Old Police Academy (OPA) was established in 1929 and was the first permanent institution to professionally train police officers until its closure in 2005. In the present day, police training is conducted at the Home Team Academy in Choa Chu Kang. For officers that trained in the OPA, some architectural icons include the Old Drill Shed, Parade Square and Swimming Pool. In particular, the Old Drill Shed was an iconic part of the OPA, as it was utilised to conduct trainings and doubled up as an event space to host ceremonies. In the future, the OPA site would be developed into a housing estate with the heritage elements incorporated. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: Im SGT Si Min, an Investigation Officer (IO) from the Central Police Division.As an IO, I gather evidence, analyse leads, interview victims, witnesses and suspects to ensure that reported crimes are investigated thoroughly.Every case is unique and it requires unwavering perseverance to leave no stone unturned in our investigations to bring the truth to light. There is fulfilment in what I do, especially when I bring closure to the victims and see justice being served to the perpetrators.However, as with every job, there are always challenges. Sometimes the cases can be complex and very often, it is a race against time to trace and arrest the suspects. We will need to have a clear mind and be flexible to adapt our strategies and plan accordingly to the evolving and dynamic situations on the ground.At the end of the day, what spurs me on is knowing that what I do can positively impact lives and contribute to a safer Singapore.SPFInFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Have you seen the Next-generation Fast Response Car (NGFRC) on the streets of Singapore? The SPFs NGFRC is integrated with smart technology to improve our operational effectiveness at the frontline.For instance, the In-Vehicle Video Recording System provides live streaming of high-resolution video footage to the Police Operations Command Centre to allow better sense-making and incident management.The Automated Number Plate Recognition system detects vehicle of interests on the move, without officers having to divert their attention from other ongoing tasks.The SPF will continually strive to explore and adopt technology to improve our frontline capabilities.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: Im SSSgt Mohamad Faizal from the Police Security Command, and Im a Personal Security Officer (PSO). As PSOs, our key task is to ensure the safety and security of our VIPs and visiting foreign dignitaries. We undergo rigorous training in close protection tactics, tactical firearms application and advanced vehicle manoeuvring tactics, amongst other skill sets. This enables us to respond swiftly and effectively to any incident when required. As our VIPs frequently meet members of the public and attend events, a challenge that we face is learning how to strike a balance between carrying out our duties and being mindful not to impede our VIPs daily activities. This is a valuable skill that all PSOs gain with experience. The ground situation is dynamic, and being a PSO means that we will always have to be vigilant and alert. This is why you probably always find us looking fierce and not smiling. We have a job to do, and we hope you understand! This job comes with a strong sense of duty and fulfilment, and that is exactly why I chose to be a PSO. SPFinFocus singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[Joint Exercise @ Raffles Lighthouse]Yesterday, , (MPA), and Police Coast Guard (PCG), conducted a joint exercise at Raffles Lighthouse located at Pulau Satumu. Codenamed Exercise Bluewhale, the exercise simulated responding to contingency scenarios which included a fire at the lighthouse, as well as the rescue of three persons who fell overboard from a ferry. As part of the exercise, a rescue jet ski and a remote-control flotation device were deployed by SCDFs Marine Firefighting Specialists to locate and rescue the casualties. Marine vessels from MPA and PCG were also deployed for cordoning and search operations. Such joint exercises serve to validate and update the respective agencies' joint operational plans and procedures, and also tests the agencies' coordination and response to a major maritime incident. MPA's tour operator, Lionheartlanders, and ferry operator, Marina South Ferries, were also involved in the exercise to practice their emergency procedures should an incident happen during one of the Raffles Lighthouse tours.Check out the photos of the exercise to see our responders in action!

Traffic Police officers keep our roads safe by educating and engaging road users on road safety behaviours, and enforcing traffic laws through their daily patrols and operations assisted by the traffic enforcement cameras.Road users play an important role in keeping our roads safe too!Be gracious, vigilant and responsible on the road so that everyone can have a safe and pleasant journey.Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility! Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday useyourroadsense
