[- ] The Traffic Police, together with the Singapore Road Safety Council (SRSC), held the Anti-Drink Drive Campaign 2023 on 29 November.As part of the campaign, the Guest-Of-Honour MOS Faishal unveiled the campaign tagline, Make the Right Choice: Dont Drink and Drive, to remind motorists to prioritise safety by refraining from driving after consuming alcohol. Remember, drink-driving is an irresponsible act and as we approach the festive season, we would like to remind all motorists to Make the Right Choice to keep our roads safe for everyone. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Yesterday morning, a counter-terrorism and emergency preparedness exercise, Exercise Heartbeat, was held in the vicinity of Millenia Singapore.This exercise simulates a multi-vector terror attack at the heart of the Marina Downtown to validate the responses by Home Team officers and our community stakeholders during an emergency.The community response - how we stay alert, stay united and stay strong - is crucial in safeguarding Singapore and our way of life.Photos by: SC2 Ryan Quek and SC Zayedsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ ()]The TBHFS is the first of its kind in Singapore in enabling highly realistic vessel simulation at speeds exceeding 50 knots. It is integrated with an advanced eye-tracking system in addition to weapon capabilities.This simulator can replicate real-world vessel behavior including wave movements and responses, which allows our Police Coast Guard officers to practise their boat handling skills and tactics for various maritime scenarios in a safe environment . Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

' : ()Launched in 2015, the POCC is the 24/7 nerve centre of the Singapore Police Force's operations. Comprising of the emergency communications group, the incident watch group and the sense making group, the POCC monitors events big and small, including taking 999 calls, and coordinates the police response to them.When an incident is reported, the POCC proactively seeks out for more information from various sources such as calls from members of public, Police cameras and social media platforms for coordinated sense-making. This information will be provided swiftly to frontline responders to aid in incident management. Additionally, the POCC coordinates island-wide responses to all incidents across Singapore, including activating additional/specialised forces to support frontline officers in managing incidents.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

[ ]Malicious drones pose a threat to our public safety and security as they can be flown into protected areas and can potentially bypass traditional security measures set up to protect a major security event.To counter this threat, the SPF and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) have developed and deployed counter drone systems that can detect and neutralise rogue drones.The handheld drone jamming system disrupts a drones control signal, stops its flight and allows the Police to retrieve the drone for investigations subsequently.The drone detection system suite consists of both detection sensors and cameras that allow the Police to detect and track the flight path of drones from afar. This allows the Police to take pre-emptive measures to locate the pilot to stop the flight before it poses a danger.The Police will continue to leverage technology to enhance our response against potential and changing threats. Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydayhtxsg

The Forensics Division of the Criminal Investigation Department is the authority on crime scene forensic matters in the SPF. Forensic Specialists leverage technology to analyse and process evidence gathered at the crime scenes efficiently and accurately to provide investigative leads. For example, fingerprints lifted at scene are screened through the Automated Fingerprint Identification Systems to identify possible suspects. Forensic specialists are also equipped with presumptive blood screening kits to perform rapid, on-site preliminary tests to differentiate between potential blood traces and other stains that resemble blood. Learn how they bring the truth to light in this weeks SPF Glossary! singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

! - - On 23rd April 2023, Senior Staff Sergeant Shaari was off-duty when he saw a man holding what seemed to be a sharp, curved object. He looked like he was in a daze. I sensed that the situation could potentially become dangerous. I asked my family to stay inside the car. My mother grew worried and tried to stop me from approaching the man. But if I let this pass, who knows what could happen next? ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

From the grandstand to the bright lights of the track, the Singapore Police and an INTERPOL Major Event Support Team worked together to ensure a safe and secure F1 weekend for all! Officers facilitated real-time exchange of messages and information among countries, including on stolen and lost travel documents.The SPF and INTERPOL have proudly been working hand in hand to secure the F1 SingaporeGP night race annually since 2016. The worlds largest policing organization is officially marking its 100-year anniversary, celebrating a century of international police cooperation. Heres to many more years of police cooperation ahead!Photos by: Naveen Raj and INTERPOLF1 SingaporeGPsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydayInterpol100PoliceCooperation

Our Crime Scene Specialists identify relevant forensic evidence at crime scenes and conduct thorough investigations to ensure that truth is brought to light Evidence at the scene is properly highlighted, marked and labelled. Blood sampling kits may be used for DNA identification and fingerprints are photographed, lifted and preserved for possible matches in the labs. All exhibits are eventually packed and secured in appropriate packaging materials to serve legal and scientific requirements and most importantly to prevent loss, alteration, damage and contamination.Which unit should we capture next? Best three comments get pinned Photos by: Naveen Raj singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

, How would you feel if the victim that had fallen to a scam was a loved one? says ASP Irina Ng, a senior investigation officer from the Anti-Scam Command (ASC) of the Commercial Affairs Department who feels the need to raise more awareness for scams.The ASC functions as a nerve centre in the fight against scams, and ASC officers including Irina work closely with partners such as the banks, FinTech companies and other government agencies to promptly follow up on cases to prevent monetary losses by victims. The challenge is to stay one step ahead. Scams ARE preventable. Stay vigilant, think before you act and question before committing any transfers.ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

This year, The Singapore Police Force Scholarship and Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) Scholarships Award Ceremony was held at The Istana on 18 August, with Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr K Shanmugam as the Guest of Honour. Inspector Edison Chua and Inspector Chen Hong Wen received The Singapore Police Force Scholarship, one of the most prestigious awards, alongside 32 other Ministry of Home Affairs Scholars that evening. Upon completion of their studies, they will undergo structured residential training at the Police Training Command that includes police defence tactics, criminal investigation, physical training, as well as leadership development. Subsequently, they will be posted to the Police Divisions to assume operational and command appointments, as part of their development to be future leaders of the Force. Congratulations to all scholarship recipients!Find out more on

The Police K-9 Unit plays an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure.The K-9 dogs and their handlers are often deployed to support other police units in frontline operations. One such pair is SSS Chia Wei and Rocky! Rocky is an Explosive Detection Dog from Australia, and he has been Chia Wei's 'partner' for the last 7 years!Rocky is trained to identify a wide range of explosive substances and is deployed with Chia Wei at various locations such as the checkpoints and airport to prevent and detect crime! Photos by: SC Ryan Queksingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

The Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU) of the Singapore Police Force responds to hostage situations, barricade incidents and attempted suicides.With their specialised training and negotiation skills, CNU officers can help save lives and bring about positive outcomes in challenging situations.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Police psychological services have existed within the Singapore Police Force since 1993 and the Police Psychological Services Department was established in April 2021.Police psychologists, such as Bryan Danni, are involved in areas of work relating to assessment psychology, leadership psychology, operations psychology, crime psychology and resilience psychology. For example, Bryan is involved in providing psychological training and counselling for police officers. He also offers operational assistance during crisis negotiation scenarios.Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

: Officers from our Police Logistics Department (PLD) play an important role in supporting, equipping and sustaining the SPFs operations at the frontline. They help put in place security infrastructures and provide officers with the necessary resources so that they can carry out their duties effectively.For this years National Day Parade, PLDofficers havestartedpreparing for the logistical requirements as early as December 2022. They coordinated with vendors and various SPF units on the deployment of the safety barricades, oversaw the setting up of walk-through metal detectors at person check stations and put up command posts and rest areas for SPF officers amongst other logistical operations.PLD officers continue to work tirelessly on the groundeven afteranevent has ended toremove the structures and barricades quickly so that normalcy can resume as soon as possible after the security operations have concluded.Kudos to our PLD logisticians who are always the first in and last out, providing timely mission-centric capabilities in supporting SPFs major operations!Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce OnwardAsOneSGNDP2023HappyBirthdaySingapore

() On 27 May afternoon, police volunteer Wayne Koo was having lunch with his friend near Whampoa.We were about to leave when we suddenly heard a loud explosion coming from the road. We saw the front engine of a recycling truck had caught fire. Instead of running away, he bravely ran towards the fire, putting out the fire together with onlookers. No one was harmed, and no other properties were damaged. DAC (V) Koo was awarded the Community First Responder Award by the SCDF in June, 2023 for his brave acts.As a VSC (Volunteer Special Constabulary)officer, sometimes you ask yourself whether you are in this for the job or for the mission. The scheme may be voluntary, but the role and mission are not. You are vested with the responsibility. We come from all walks of life. But once you put on that blue uniform, all of us are equal. Its meaningful and I want to step forward to inspire others. ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

This morning, four officers from the Singapore Police Force (SPF) took part in the Community Chest Vertical Marathon - a 57-storey climb, at the Marina Bay Sands. This event, co-organised by Community Chest and Marina Bay Sands, aims to rally the community to build a caring and inclusive society for all.The SPF team comprising Eng Kiong, Junqiang, Subas and Bigyan, emerged champion with a combined timing of 28min 17s. The SPF is proud to be part of this meaningful event that brings together people from all walks of life to raise funds for the less fortunate in Singapore.For more than 30 years, the SPF had been supporting the Community Chest to care for the disadvantaged in our community.singaporepoliceforce

Constructed in 2006, the Boarding and Search Trainer (BST) is purpose-built and designed to resemble a merchant cargo vessel. The BST provides a realistic training environment for Police Coast Guard (PCG) officers to train their operational tactics. The BST has a 25 meters indoor firing range that is specially designed for various tactical firearms training. Thunder flashes and stun grenades can be deployed in the range to support complex training requirements. It also comes installed with a Range Management System allowing officers to remotely manage the electronic target system and simulate various lighting conditions and sound environments. The newly installed Rope Access Platform consists of fast roping beams and rappelling anchor points. This facility allows multiple personnel to descend simultaneously, providing a rapid and efficient means of insertion into a hostile vessel. This new platform will enable officers to train and practise quick and safe descent from elevated positions to a cushioned lower platform. There are also Close-Quarters Battle Areas within the BST that can accommodate both live firing and non-live firing trainings. The non-live firing area consists of single to multiple rooms setting, and the rooms are built with hidden compartments and false ceilings to train officers in vessel rummaging. The live-firing area in each deck is made up of a modular layout that allows the setup for the deck to be changed for each training session, helping to increase the realism of the training as the participants cannot predict the decks layout. The BST enhances the training of PCG officers to ensure they are operationally ready to safeguard Singapores territorial waters every day. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

The live-firing area in each deck is made up of a modular layout that allows the setup for the deck to be changed for each training session, helping to increase the realism of the training as the participants cannot predict the decks layout. The BST enhances the training of PCG officers to ensure they are operationally ready to safeguard Singapores territorial waters every day. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Constructed in 2006, the Boarding and Search Trainer (BST) is purpose-built and designed to resemble a merchant cargo vessel. The BST provides a realistic training environment for Police Coast Guard (PCG) officers to train their operational tactics. The BST has a 25 meters indoor firing range that is specially designed for various tactical firearms training. Thunder flashes and stun grenades can be deployed in the range to support complex training requirements. It also comes installed with a Range Management System allowing officers to remotely manage the electronic target system and simulate various lighting conditions and sound environments. The newly installed Rope Access Platform consists of fast roping beams and rappelling anchor points. This facility allows multiple personnel to descend simultaneously, providing a rapid and efficient means of insertion into a hostile vessel. This new platform will enable officers to train and practise quick and safe descent from elevated positions to a cushioned lower platform. There are also Close-Quarters Battle Areas within the BST that can accommodate both live firing and non-live firing trainings. The non-live firing area consists of single to multiple rooms setting, and the rooms are built with hidden compartments and false ceilings to train officers in vessel rummaging. The live-firing area in each deck is made up of a modular layout that allows the setup for the deck to be changed for each training session, helping to increase the realism of the training as the participants cannot predict the decks layout. The BST enhances the training of PCG officers to ensure they are operationally ready to safeguard Singapores territorial waters every day. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

The Tactical Strike Vehicle (TSV) is part of the fleet of vehicles under the Special Operations Command (SOC) to augment its tactical capabilities and protection. These vehicles are heavily fortified with protective wire mesh and armored bodies, ensuring they are well shielded to effectively counter and neutralize potential threats. Equipped with features such as a public announcement system, blinkers and floodlights, the TSVs project a strong police presence, acting as a deterrent to perpetrators. The TSVs are also equipped with an array of powerful cameras to facilitate sensemaking and threat detection.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[ !]The Police Community Roadshow (PCR) has made a comeback after a five-year hiatus!This years PCR features the latest technologies and equipment used by the SPF to keep our community safe and secure, which include the Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, the Next Generation Fast Response Car and various weaponry.There will also be live demonstrations of the SPFs capabilities, and performances by the SPF band and the Police K-9 unit. In addition, visitors can experience hands-on crime scene investigations in a mock-up scene.So what are you waiting for? Join us at the PCR at One Punggol today!policecommunityroadshow2023 singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

- On 10 May 2023 at about 12pm, Yi Jun and Chong Wei were out for brunch with their family at a coffeeshop in Woodlands when they encountered an incident with a man wielding a chopper.The brother-sister duo recount how they quickly worked together to disarm him before calling for the Police to arrest the man.When asked about how they acted in this incident, Yi Jun mentioned that as police officers we are trained to look out for security threats and to stop them immediately if we are able to do so. We feel this way even when were off-duty! Chong Wei also mentioned that he was happy that they were able to resolve the incident quickly with no harm done to anyone. I just wanted to play a bigger role in helping keep Singapore and my community safe, which is why I chose to join the SPF.ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

- On 10 May 2023 at about 12pm, Yi Jun and Chong Wei were out for brunch with their family at a coffeeshop in Woodlands when they encountered an incident with a man wielding a chopper.The brother-sister duo recount how they quickly worked together to disarm him before calling for the Police to arrest the man.When asked about how they acted in this incident, Yi Jun mentioned that as police officers we are trained to look out for security threats and to stop them immediately if we are able to do so. We feel this way even when were off-duty! Chong Wei also mentioned that he was happy that they were able to resolve the incident quickly with no harm done to anyone. I just wanted to play a bigger role in helping keep Singapore and my community safe, which is why I chose to join the SPF.ourpolicestories singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

() , Inspired by the Hong Kong TV police dramas in the 1990s, AC Serene Chiu joined the Singapore Police Force in 1999. She has since stayed on for over 23 years.For officers who have worked with her, you would have known her as someone who is jovial, yet focused, driven and firm during operations and missions. AC Serene Chiu now leads Clementi Police Division, which was recently named the Best Land Division at the Police Day Parade on 3 June 2023. Today, we speak to her to find out what are the secrets in winning the award.Theres no secret in winning (laughs)! But I do like to credit my officers for maintaining a high standard of operational excellence and professionalism. They will chase down every lead to solve every crime they can and ensure justice is served. The Division is outstanding because of its people who give their utmost to keep Singapore safe and secure every day.And of course, I would also like to thank our community partners and stakeholders, who have actively contributed to creating safer communities. Technology plays an important role too. We use data-driven approach to identify crime patterns to better plan our deterrence patrols and crime prevention efforts, and Police cameras have been effective in helping us deter and solve crimes.[To be continued]

- The Singapore Police Force (SPF) held the Police Day Parade 2023 on 3 June 2023 at the Home Team Academy. Mr Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister (DPM) and Minister for Finance, was the Guest-of-Honour at the parade which saw 650 participants from the various Police divisions, specialist units, Volunteer Special Constabulary, and cadets from the National Police Cadet Corps.Commemorated annually on 3 June since 1971, Police Day celebrates the SPFs achievements, recognises the contributions of past and present officers, and brings officers together to renew our pledge to serve Singapore and to carry out our duties with courage, loyalty, integrity, and fairness.Here are some photos taken at the Parade yesterday!policeday2023

- () , You would have known Insp Majid if you were a police trainee who had graduated from the Police Training Command over the past decade.Majid is a Field Instructor and as the Parade Conducting Officer for Police Day Parade 2023, he is responsible for conducting drill training and rehearsals for officers participating in the Parade. As a trainer, I emphasise a high standard of drill for parades and ceremonies from the officers. It is an honour to be the Parade Conducting Officer and I'm confident that the officers would do the SPF proud in this years Police Day Parade.Join us at the Police Day Parade 2023 as we bring the Parade LIVE to you on SPF's Facebook page from 5:45pm tomorrow! PS: How many of you have seen, heard or trained by him during your training? Share your experience with us! Photos by: Naveen Rajpoliceday2023

: On 20 March 2022, after drinks with his friends at a restaurant along Merchant Road, 29-year-old Justin Chua left the group for a while to head to a nearby convenience store at about 10.45pm. In a flash and without any warning, he was struck on the back of his head multiple times with a glass bottle and assaulted by a group of men.With the assistance of the Police cameras and the use of Video Analytics, the Police managed to track down those responsible for the attack and arrested all of them within two weeks of the reported crime.crimefiles singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: At the recently concluded SEA Games 2023, SC/Cpl Nufail Raiyan from the Protective Security Command (ProCom) and SGT Felissa Lai from Woodlands Division clinched the silver and bronze medals respectively in the mens and womens field hockey team event.When speaking to Felissa, she mentioned that as a Ground Response Force officer, good teamwork and clear communications are key to success in any operations. Likewise, in team sports like field hockey, it is important that everyone of us work together as a team and communicate effective on the pitch so that we can execute our game plan effectively. She added that she is thankful to her Team Leader and her teammates for their support, so that she could concentrate on achieving the best results at the Games.Raiyan added that his training at ProCom taught him to be resilient and always give his best in whatever he does. His efforts will pay off at the end of the day. He adopted this mentality in every match during the SEA Games. Raiyan said, I am thankful to my family and friends as well as my teammates and colleagues in ProCom for their encouragement. I wouldnt have done it without them!Congratulations to Felissa and Raiyan for their wins!Pic 1: Felissa (left) with her teammatePic 2: Photo of SGT FelissaPic 3: Raiyan at the Sea Games 2023 Pic 4: Photo of SC/Cpl Raiyan

- : Man Kumar (K): In the late morning of 25 Mar 2023, my team and I were driving in the vicinity of Woodlands Industrial Park. Sabin (S): While driving, I spotted what appeared to be a cyclist lying on the road. He looked to be unconscious. We all sensed that there was something amiss. Dinesh Limbu (D): We quickly stopped our vehicle and dashed over to him. Jeevan Gharti (J): The cyclist was unresponsive to our calls. When Dinesh and I checked for his pulse, we found out that there was no breathing. K: We realised that this was a matter of life and death. I instructed Dinesh and Jeevan to quickly perform CPR on him. D: Although all of us are trained in CPR, it was my first time doing it in a real life scenario. All I could think about was how to save this persons life. K: As I was giving a call to the ambulance, Sabin ensured safety by blocking the road lane and directing traffic. S: We also helped to move the cyclist to a shaded grass patch nearby and continued to perform CPR. J: The ambulance soon arrived and he was conveyed to the hospital. We later learned that the cyclist had survived and was eventually discharged. K: I feel very proud of my team. We handled a critical situation effectively. D: Protecting lives and properties are always key objectives in our missions. K: We are just happy that we are able to save a precious life. I hope he is recovering well! singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

S: We also helped to move the cyclist to a shaded grass patch nearby and continued to perform CPR. J: The ambulance soon arrived and he was conveyed to the hospital. We later learned that the cyclist had survived and was eventually discharged. K: I feel very proud of my team. We handled a critical situation effectively. D: Protecting lives and properties are always key objectives in our missions. K: We are just happy that we are able to save a precious life. I hope he is recovering well! singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Scam alert! Check out the following infographics on how scammers have used a fake ScamShield App for their latest phishing scam. Do not download any files from third-party or dubious sites to your device. This may lead to phishing malware being installed unknowingly, which allows scammers to take control of your device to steal personal/banking information for unauthorised transactions! If you have any information relating to such crimes or when in doubt, please call the Police Hotline at 1800-255-0000, or submit information online at For more information on scams, members of the public can visit or call the Anti-Scam Helpline at 1800-722-6688.

/ !At the ongoing SEA Games 2023, SC/SGT Ethan Poh from Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) and his team mates clinched the men's table tennis (team) gold medal for Singapore! Ethan grabbed another bronze medal earlier today at the Men's Double competition. When speaking to Ethan, Discipline and determination are two key values that I picked up through police trainings at the Home Team Academy.Small things like doing stretching daily and eating healthily may seem mundane, but they go a long way in helping me excel in sports. Being disciplined and having great determination to succeed helped me pull through.Ethan added that he would not have been able to focus on his competition without the full support from his family and his team at TransCom. His achievements would not have been possible without their support.Congratulations to Ethan and the men's table tennis team, and all the best to our Team Singapore athletes competing in the remaining competitions at SEA Games 2023!

My two-and-a-half years old twin girls were either asleep when I got home, or when I left for work, recalled DAC Tay of the early days of her Checkpoints posting, when her team had to conduct multiple exercises at the checkpoints during odd hours, in order to avoid the morning and evening peak periods.That was when my mum guilt would kick in, she shared, but at the end of the day, everything worked out because of the strong support I received from my family, supervisors and team. Now that her twins are 12 years old, DAC Tay says with a chuckle that shes become their excuse to stay up past bedtime, as they eagerly wait for me to come home after my work! Happy Mothers Day to all the mothers out there!

The Police have arrested a 52-year-old man for his suspected involvement in a case of outrage of modesty.On 11 April 2023 at about 9.50pm, the Police were alerted to an incident where a woman was purportedly molested by a man in the vicinity of Changi Road.Through ground enquiries, coordination with the Police Operations Command Centre, and with the aid of Police cameras and the use of video analytics, officers from Bedok Police Division located the 52-year-old man and arrested him along Haig Road at 12.20am on 12 April 2023, within three hours of the reported crime.The man will be charged on 13 April 2023 with outrage of modesty under Section 354(1) of the Penal Code 1871. The offence carries an imprisonment term which may extend to three years, or a fine, or caning, or any combination of such punishments.

[ ]On 10 April 2023 at 4.56pm, the Police were informed that a man was lost in the forested area within the MacRitchie Nature Trail & Reservoir Park.Police resources including officers from Tanglin Division, Gurkha Contingent and the Aerial Response Team were swiftly deployed to locate the missing man. Officers from and also assisted in the search.The missing man was subsequently located at 7.02pm. He was found together with a fellow male hiker. Both men, aged 67 and 51, were unhurt.NParks would also like to advise the public to stay on the designated trails while trekking, and observe the opening hours of our nature reserves and nature parks, which are 7am to 7pm. For urgent matters, they can call the NParks helpline at 1800-471 7300.

Our Police Stories - International Womens Day special Since their entry into the Force in 1949, female police officers have been constantly pushing their boundaries to achieve greater heights in an otherwise male-dominated profession. Meet INSP Stephanie Lim, one of the female officers currently serving in the SPF. Let us take a moment on International Womens Day today, to embraceequity and recognise the contributions of all policewomen in the Force. In addition to static traffic enforcement cameras deployed across Singapore, the Traffic Police deploys portable speed laser cameras to deter and detect speeding.Manned by a single officer, this portable speed laser camera is compact and easy to deploy. It is capable of capturing high-resolution images and works well even in low-light conditions. The violations captured from these cameras will then be processed accordingly.The portable speed laser cameras are but one tool available to the Traffic Police. While we will continue our three-pronged approach to maintain safer roads through education, engagement, and enforcement, we need all road users to continue practising good road safety habits and play their part in keeping Singapores roads safe. Remember, road safety is a shared responsibility.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

: A series of brutal attacks along various locations in Tanjong Pagar left one of the victims with multiple facial fractures and warded in the intensive care unit.Officers involved in the case were relentless in their investigations. - Looking forward to catching Blackpink, Harry Styles or buying tickets to other big concerts this year? Read this before you become first in line for a concert ticket scam! In 2022, over 199 police reports were made in relation to scams involving concert tickets with victims suffering losses of at least $175,000! This was more than 48 times the amount lost for the same period in 2021! So heres some advice if youre looking to buy from third-party resellers: Physically meet with the seller to verify the tickets BEFORE making payment, no matter how eager you are Choose buyer protection within the platform and avoid making advance payments Buy only from authorised sellers or reputable sources Stay safe and enjoy the music! spotthesignssgscamalert

, : & .Ibnu Musalli (I): I always find that police officers are in a unique position to make a difference to victims and vulnerable persons. There are so many different incidents we attend to. Foot chases can be exciting but sometimes there are other cases which bring a different kind of meaningfulness.Miqdad Fisall (M): Just last month, Ibnu and I received a call for police assistance on 27 November evening stating that a woman had been reported missing.I: Yes, the caller was her relative and was troubled by the fact that she was uncontactable for the past four days. He had even gone to her apartment unit to make checks but had gotten no response from her. Her mobile phone was switched off as well.M: Were familiar with the terrain here at Clementi NPC and quickly headed down to make enquiries at her apartment building.I: We made some quick checks with her neighbours. What the neighbours said were consistent with the relative. They had not seen the missing lady for three or four days. M: We also noticed that there were a few delivery parcels that have been left outside her house.I: However, our instincts and experience told us that she might still be in her unit but in a condition where she couldnt respond.M: As we were speaking to the neighbours, we heard some faint rapping sounds coming from the other side of the wall. This further confirmed our suspicions that she might still be inside.I: We had to act quickly so with the help of the security guard, we managed to gain access to her unit.M: The house was dimly-lit and appeared to be empty. As we walked further in, the faint knocking began to grow louder. I: Yes, the source of knocking seemed to be coming from the bathroom area.M: I cried out Miss, we are the Police! Were here to help you! To our relief, she responded![To be continued in comment section]

- The Police K-9 Unit plays an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure.The Police Dog Unit (former name of the Police K-9 Unit) was first established in 1955, and the dogs were mainly trained to track suspects and to conduct patrols.Over time, the unit has grown both in size and capabilities. In 2003, it was renamed as the Police K-9 Unit and reorganised to be part of the newly established Special Operations Command.Today, there are more than 230 working dogs in the Police K-9 Unit, and they play key roles in various police operations, ranging from finding explosives, tracking missing persons to providing security coverage for major events.

- - Post-blast investigation (PBI) is a key operational capability for the SPF, especially with the existing threat of terrorism.The SPF works closely with local and foreign stakeholders to ensure that we remainoperationally ready and competent to deal with bomb-blast incidents."Exercise Solar Wind is an important platform that provides a realistic training environment for officers from the Singapore Police Force and the Royal Brunei Police Force to jointly undergo PBI training. We will continue to work with our strategic partners to enhance our PBI capabilities. " - Deputy Commissioner of Police (Investigation & Intelligence), Mr How Kwang Hweesafeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforce

, : , . .My family and I were enjoying our afternoon at home during my day off on 28 Sep 2020. This peacefulness was interrupted when we suddenly heard screams of a woman coming from downstairs. My house on the third floor overlooks the carpark. As I peered out, a shocking sight greeted me a young lady was frantically fleeing from a knife-wielding man!The woman was screaming and clearly in distress. I know this might sound quite dramatic but I quickly dashed out of the house while telling my family members I need to go down, I need to save the girl!.It wasnt wise to confront a man with a knife alone so as I ran past some migrant workers who were working nearby, I asked if they had anything I could use to protect myself. They quickly handed me a hoe from their worksite and I ran towards the couple.Once at the carpark, I saw that a driver had stopped and used his car to block the man from reaching the woman. The man was still waving his knife and shouting incoherently.A crowd had already formed by then. For everyones safety, I knew I had to defuse the situation as soon as possible. I addressed him calmly. Im a police officer. Please drop your knife.Suddenly, he began charging towards me with his knife. Fortunately, I managed to deflect his blow by quickly swinging the hoe at him. He backed away. I saw the mans eyes darting around when he realised that there wasnt anywhere for him to run. The crowd had him surrounded. In a panic, he pointed the knife towards himself and started slashing at his own arms.I took this chance to quickly grab his wrist and disarmed him. Some nearby onlookers then rushed in and together we successfully subdued the man. Soon enough, police officers arrived and arrested him. Both the man and woman were later brought to a hospital to treat their injuries. [To be continued in comment section]

Some nearby onlookers then rushed in and together we successfully subdued the man. Soon enough, police officers arrived and arrested him. Both the man and woman were later brought to a hospital to treat their injuries. [To be continued in comment section]

Community policing is one of the key thrusts of the Singapore Police Forces policing strategy to actively involve the community in keeping Singapore safe and secure. In the 1970s and 80s, the Police were faced with rising crime cases. To better fight crime, community-based policing strategy was introduced via the Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) system in 1983. The NPP system focused on leveraging community support in the areas of crime prevention and detection. In 1997, the NPP system evolved into the Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) system. The NPCs serve as one-stop policing centres and bring a wider range of police services closer to the community. The Community Policing System (COPS) system was introduced in 2012 to further strengthen our partnership with the community. Under COPS, the Community Policing Unit (CPU) was formed as a full-fledged unit to take on community policing roles. Clad in their signature white polo tees and blue bermudas, CPU officers build closer relationships with the community and stakeholders through physical and online engagements. Over the years, volunteer schemes such as the Community Watch Scheme (CWS), Citizens on Patrol (COP), Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC) and VSC (Community) have also been introduced to empower the community to be our Enabled Police Partners. These volunteers play an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure. Interested in partnering with us? Join us as a volunteer (link in bio).

, : , . .SI Fadzly (F): There are many tourist spots and commercial areas within the jurisdiction of Marina Bay NPC so we see a lot of different types of cases.SGT Junjie (JJ): On 16 July this year, we received a report that a girl had gone missing from her hotel room.ASP Benjamin (B): We moved quickly and met up with the girls parents at their hotel lobby.JJ: Being tourists, they were understandably distraught and worried as their daughter had gone missing in a foreign country. They also shared with us that she was suffering from anxiety and mental health issues.B: Learning this, our priority was to find the missing girl to prevent her from any possible harms. I apprised my officers quickly and all of us sprung into action.F: We needed to quickly come up with a plan. Which likely direction would their daughter have headed off to? How do we best deploy our officers?B: Im thankful that my team has a high level of competency. Everyone stepped up to the plate to do what they needed to do.F: While some of my colleagues went to the command centre to check the CCTVs, the others relayed the descriptions of the missing girl to the Police Operations Command Centre so that they can disseminate the information to all frontline police officers.JJ: Concurrently, we checked with the parents and learned that their daughter had a location-sharing app activated on her phone. Fadzly and I tracked to her last-known location within the hotel premises where we eventually found her.[To be continued in comment section]

The Police Tactical Unit (PTU) is a strategic force under the Special Operations Command that supports the Singapore Police Force in managing public order and public security incidents. The history of the PTU dates back to the formation of the first Riot Squad in 1952, following the Maria Hertogh riots, the first post-war major riot in Singapore. This was followed by the establishment of the first Reserve Unit (RU) in 1953, which was made up of three troops of 50 regular officers, to respond to riot control and disaster management. The RU was later renamed as the Police Task Force in 1980, before eventually being renamed in 2005 to the PTU as we know of today. The PTU is a highly-trained and well-equipped outfit tasked to handle public order and public security incidents on land, offshore, and maritime environments. The unit conducts regular patrols at high footfall locations in Singapore and also supports major operations.

, : Being an Emergency Response Team (ERT) officer at Bedok Police Division has been a childhood dream come true for me. I enjoy the tactical trainings, I like my job, and every day brings about something new. This is probably why I like to stay active during my off-days as well. I first signed up for the MyResponder app back in 2017, which alerts members of the public to nearby emergency cases. Being a police officer, I am trained in CPR. I thought to myself - why not put these skills to good use? Thus far, Ive been activated seven times via the app to cases where someone in my vicinity needed assistance. The first time I got activated was in 2020. I was at home when the alert of a Suspected Cardiac Arrest popped up stating that someone in the neighbouring condo unit needed assistance. I quickly rushed over and sought the help of the security guard to bring me up to the unit. We found an elderly man who had collapsed between some furniture. I had to think quick on my feet. We repositioned the man and I asked the security guard to assist me with the AED as I conducted CPR. Fortunately, the paramedics soon arrived and conveyed him to the hospital. The most recent incident happened earlier in April this year. Since this wasnt my first activation, I already had a personal process set in place to ensure I was fully prepared to assist when on the scene: (i) receive the alert, (ii) check for the nearest AED then (iii) head to the location. When I arrived, a crowd of onlookers had already formed. I saw a lady attempting to do CPR on an elderly man with the assistance of an SCDF operator on the phone. I quickly took over from the lady until paramedics arrived. I then found out that the elderly mans bicycle was still at the scene. With the help of a neighbour, we returned the bicycle to his unit where we also informed his daughter on what had happened. [To be continued in comment section]

In the 1930s, the Mobile Police Patrolmen were a familiar sight in the streets of pre-war Singapore. Clad in their white uniform and black boots, these officers rode their Birmingham Small Arms (BSA) Company motorcycles - one of the first motorcycles commissioned for the Traffic Police (TP) of yesteryear.As Singapore's roads evolved, so did our TP - TP patrol officers now use the BMW R 1250RT motorcycles for patrols and to respond to incidents. Packed with safety features such as the Anti-lock Braking System and traction control, our TP officers are now much better equipped to conduct their traffic enforcements safely and effectively.policeheritage

, : & - . SI Kelly Goh (K): I was considering my career choices when I was younger and I recall my classmate saying to me, Come to the sea, its very fun. Who knew that I would end up spending 18 years as a PCG officer. (laughs) SSS Nur Haqim (H): Five years ago, I was a GRF officer at Changi NPC and the switch from land to sea was interesting! I made the switch as I wanted to learn about seamanship and pick up new skills. K: This incident happened on 11 July last year. It was around 1pm in the afternoon, and we were out performing sea patrol. The sea-state was choppy with strong winds. H: Yes, the weather was bad. We received an alert regarding a boat that had capsized somewhere along the sea off East Coast Park and we proceeded to the scene immediately. K: From afar, we sighted two men in the water holding on to the sides of a capsized sailboat. Thankfully, they had lifejackets on. H: The men were exhausted from being in the water and multiple attempts of righting their sailboat. We helped them onboard our craft and found out that they lost control of their sailboat on their way to the jetty when the weather turned bad. K: We confirmed that they didnt require medical attention, and offered to assist them to flip over their capsized boat. H: It was my first time helping to overturn a vessel at sea, so in my head I was recollecting what I learnt during training. Together with my crewmates, we threw a rope to tie their vessel to ours. Then all of us pulled hard to flip the boat. K: While all of them were outside in the rain, I was inside our boat, at the helm. (laughs) H: Haha yes, but Kellys job is actually the most difficult! K: It wasnt easy controlling the boat and keeping it steady in that rough sea-state. H: Eventually, we managed to flip the boat over. The mens belongings were floating around the water, so we helped to retrieve the items for them as well.[continued]

In the 1970s, police patrol cars served predominantly as a mode of transport for officers to respond to crime scenes and to patrol the neighbourhoods. They were fitted with basic equipment such as the siren and loud hailer .Today, our police patrol cars are more than just a mode of transport. In 2020, the SPF rolled out the Next-generation Fast Response Car.Two key features of these cars include the Automated Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) system and the In-Vehicle Video Recording System (IVVRS).The ANPR system detects vehicle of interest on the move, without officers having to divert their attention from other ongoing tasks while the IVVRS provides live streaming of high-resolution video footage to the Police Operations Command Centre that allows for better sense-making and incident management. policeheritage

In the 1970s, police patrol cars served predominantly as a mode of transport for officers to respond to crime scenes and to patrol the neighbourhoods. They were fitted with basic equipment such as the siren and loud hailer .Today, our police patrol cars are more than just a mode of transport. In 2020, the SPF rolled out the Next-generation Fast Response Car.Two key features of these cars include the Automated Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) system and the In-Vehicle Video Recording System (IVVRS).The ANPR system detects vehicle of interest on the move, without officers having to divert their attention from other ongoing tasks while the IVVRS provides live streaming of high-resolution video footage to the Police Operations Command Centre that allows for better sense-making and incident management. policeheritage

() On 5 August 2022, SC/Sgt Afiq Aliuddin Bin Azhar and three of his colleagues were on board the train when they were approached by a student from Orchid Park Secondary School. Little did they expect to receive a post-it note from her expressing her gratitude towards the officers for serving our nation Every day, our Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) officers conduct patrols and checks at our public land transport system to safeguard us against crime. These heart-warming gestures are testament to our officers hard work and inspire us in our pursuit to keep Singapore safe and secure. singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydayStrongerTogether Majulah NDP2022

, : & / . . .SGT Ayden Goh (A): This incident happened on 15 Aug 2021. Nick and I overheard a member of the public informing our counter officer that she saw an elderly man at one of the blocks nearby who looked like he needed some assistance.V/SGT Nick Koh (N): Ayden and I quickly headed over to see if we could offer help.A: We soon found the elderly man sitting on a bench under one of the blocks. He looked to be in his seventies and seemed a little short of breath. He was unable to tell us his address.N: We learnt that he had lodged a report regarding his missing phone at the NPC earlier, so we checked with our counter officer for his address and details of his next-of-kin.A: We helped him up but he suddenly lost consciousness and collapsed on me. I quickly grabbed hold of him before he hit the floor.N: We checked for his pulse. There was no breathing. We had to act fast and I immediately initiated CPR on him. Although this was my first time doing so, I was surprised that I did not have any fear and my first-aid training had kicked in allowing me to act instantly.A: While Nick was attending to the man, I called for an ambulance and relayed the information to the rest of my team. I then rushed to grab the nearest AED and set it up as Nick continued to do the compressions.N: I knew that these first few minutes were extremely crucial and my thoughts were just focused on saving the man.A: Yes, the reality struck me that his life was at stake.N: Paramedics soon arrived but we were still unable to resuscitate him before he was conveyed to the hospital.A: I felt quite affected by the whole incident. I found myself asking whether there was anything else we could have done more or have acted sooner. Nick came to assure me that we did the best we could.[continued]

The Police Coast Guard (PCG), formerly known as the Marine Police, has come a long way from its humble beginnings to become a professional and modern unit that safeguards Singapore's territorial waters today.In 1951, 200 men were drafted to the Marine Police to operate a new fleet of boats. The majority of them had no experience in organised seamanship other than experience on fishing vessels. Throughout the rest of the year, classes were organised for officers to be qualified Steersman to operate the boat and to improve the operational effectiveness of the unit.Today, all our frontline PCG officers are trained in seamanship, navigation, boat handling and weaponry, to deter and detect criminal activities out at sea.In June 2022, PCG commissioned the 5th Generation PT Class Patrol Craft with features such as the remote weapon system, waterjet propulsion for speed manoeuvrability, and improved sensors for surveillance and navigation. The addition of these new boats further enhanced PCGs crime-fighting capabilities at the frontline.policeheritage

, : & . . SGT Nur Fadilah (N): It was about 10pm on 22 June when we received a call telling us that a unit at Marsiling Crescent was on fire. Franco was my patrol partner that night. Hes a full-time Police National Serviceman who joined the Woodlands West NPC just two months ago. SC Franco Kam (F): Being a GRF officer has been an eye-opening experience! I felt quite assured being with Fadilah as we headed to the scene. Shes been in the Force for over 13 years. N: As we entered the carpark, we saw a group of residents had already gathered at the foot of the block. I looked up and saw thick black smoke coming out from the unit on the second floor. N: When they saw our vehicle, the residents started waving at us to get our attention. One of the residents urgently told us that there were people still trapped in the unit. We had to act fast. F: It was shocking to see that the smoke had reached all the way down to the first floor lift landing. With a fire extinguisher in hand, I ran up the stairwell together with Fadilah. N: Outside the unit, the smoke was tremendously thick and we had poor visibility. Franco started calling out Is there anyone inside?. That was when we heard cries coming from the living room. F: We didnt think twice. Both of us immediately dashed into the burning unit towards the sound of the crying child. I searched around with my torchlight and saw a small boy curled up on the living room floor. N: I remembered thinking how much the boy reminded me of my three-year-old son at home and how important it was to get him to safety. He grabbed on to me tightly as I quickly carried him on my shoulders and ran out of the house. [continued]

Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) Paul Lim is a father of two and an NS division commander in the Protective Security Command (ProCom). He shares with us his perspectives playing both roles: Being an NS leader is very much like being a father. I lead by example, set the right tone and set the right processes. This isn't very much different from being a father at home to my children. I have a 4-year-old son and a 2-year-old daughter. I'm always the happiest when spending time with them and making them laugh. But I do treat my NSmen like family, and I make sure I do my best to interact with every single one of them and know them personally. Some of them just want to be recognised, and being recognised by their supervisor gives them a lot of pride, so they feel very accomplished when they come back for reservist duties at ProCom. I have always approached the roles of being a father and an NS leader with the same positive attitude and enthusiasm, so I don't find it a problem to juggle both roles. In fact, my children get very excited whenever they see me in uniform!When asked on what makes him proud, DSP Paul said: Seeing my children grow up with the right values and attitudes, thinking on their feet and respecting people around them. This is very much like leading an NS division as well - when officers improve and show that they are motivated and know what to do in challenging situations, that makes me proud that I am working with such capable officers in ProCom. DSP Paul has some final words as advice: Treasure your wives and partners! They will be the ones holding the fort at home when you're on duty. Give them a nice treat whenever you can and they will appreciate it.Happy Father's Day to all the amazing and dedicated fathers out there! HappyFathersDayNS55singaporepoliceforce

'Justice Is Done 2' was written in the shadow of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has upended the world in unimaginable ways. Overnight, many countries went into lockdown in a bid to stem the spread of the virus. Normal life came to a standstill while the death toll soared. This enormous loss is a reminder that every life that has been cut short is precious. And this is what motivates our Police officers in their relentless drive to seek justice for victims of crime.'Justice Is Done 2' explores how investigators solved some of the most intractable murder cases of our time. But as much as the book highlights their efforts, it also honours the unsung heroescrime scene specialists and forensic scientistswho had toiled behind the scenes to put the cuffs on the perpetrators.Download a digital copy of the book (PDF/8.01 MB) via link in bio.JusticeIsDonesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

In this line of duty, you can expect some risks on the job. Ive been in the Traffic Police for about eight years. My father was a TP officer too, so when he first learned that I joined, he was a little worried for my safety. I was undeterred though, because Ive always felt the need to serve in the force. It was about 9pm on 17 Nov 2017. I was out on patrol and on my way back to TP HQ. I was riding along Bedok Reservoir Road when I spotted a driver in a white Maserati car who wasnt wearing a seatbelt. I signalled for the car to stop a few times but he wasnt complying. My gut feeling told me something felt a bit off. The car only came to a stop due to the red traffic light ahead. I then parked my motorcycle ahead of his vehicle and approached the driver. The drivers window was wound down. I directed for him to reverse his vehicle nearer to the bus bay behind. However the moment the traffic lights turned green, he abruptly swerved to the right and accelerated his car. I was caught by surprise and since I was standing near the drivers window, my jacket got caught at the cars window frame. The vehicle continued to speed up with my arm still dangling from the window. Everything happened so quickly. I was dragged for about 124 meters before I managed to free myself. As I lay injured on the road, a few bystanders came to my aid. Paramedics arrived soon after. I was given 20 days medical leave for injuries to my knee, neck and back. The driver was eventually charged in court. After the incident, I did feel a bit down and wondered if I could continue to work due to my injuries. I honestly enjoy my job and would very much like to resume patrolling if I am certified fit to do so. To my relief and after taking a year to recover from my injuries, Im now back on the road. I count myself blessed to have the support from my wife and colleagues. As a traffic patrol officer, even the most routine traffic stop may result in rather unexpected outcome. But this doesnt deter me from doing what I love. In fact, I feel its made me a better patrol officer today.mydutymycallingsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Visit our virtual exhibition to answer the question, and participate in this contest to stand a chance of winning a set of three SPF diecast vehicles! Five winners will be picked through a lucky draw. : ? This is what you need to do to participate in the contest: (i) Like this post.(ii) Access our SPF200 Virtual Tour @ (Link in Bio) to find the answers. We will pick 5 winners who got the right answer from a lucky draw and announce the results on 3 June 2022 via SPFs Instagram Story and DM. Good luck!policeday2022

Deputy Superintendent of Police (DSP) Khamisah, a mother of three, is a Chief Investigation Officer at Jurong Police Division. Her son, SC Muhamad Fares Aw, is currently serving his National Service at the Special Operations Command asan Assistant Trainer.DSP Khamisah recounted the early stages of her motherhoodwhiletrying to balance her roles as a mother and a police officer. It was challenging to balance work demands and spending quality time with the children. She also recalled those days fondly in which she had to get her colleagues to babysit Fares while she settled urgent work matters.However, during her off days, she made sure that she would bring her children for outings or spend time with them at home."I watched him (Fares) grow from a baby to a toddler, a teenager and now, a police officer! It is amazing and I am proud that he is serving the nation as a police officer!"SC Muhamad Fares used to think that policing was an easy job due to his mother's jovial personality. He learnt otherwise after being enlisted intheSPF. This Mother's Day, he would like to share these heartfelt thoughts to his mother:"Having gone through trainings and policing work, I realised the challenging demands and expectations of a police officer. I understand that it must not have been easy for my mother to carve out a successful policing career and at the same time, be a good mother to my siblings andme. I want to let her know that I have the utmost respect for her and I feel so lucky to have her as my mother. I love you, Ma!".Happy Mother's Day to all the amazing and noble mothers out there!happymothersdaysafeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceday

, : , / -, Wei Jie (W): Usually when new officers first join the team, it can be quite suay (unlucky). Unsurprisingly, it was Amrus first ever shift with us.K-Ron (K) and Amru (A): (laughs)K: When we received the call on 16 April at about 6pm, I was expecting a small fire usually those caused by unattended cooking - since Ive attended to those before. I only realised that wasnt the case when we turned into the street and saw the thick black smoke rising from a distance.A: A crowd had already gathered in front of the landed unit. At this point I was trying hard to recall what I learnt back in TraCom (Training Command) and to apply them at the scene. Im still so new, but I understood the basics of teamwork and looking out for each other.K: Once we parked, I grabbed a fire extinguisher from the car boot and the three of us sprinted into the house. The occupants were on the ground floor, and they pointed upwards saying that their Ah ma (grandmother) was still on the second floor.A: While Wei Jie and K-Ron ran upstairs, I stayed behind to reassure the family members and helped to prevent more crowd from gathering.W: I was quite shocked to learn how dark it was upstairs due to the density of the smoke.K: Yes, we couldnt see clearly in the thick smoke and decided to stick together.W: Actually, it was so dark I didnt even realize you were standing behind me. But I could hear you.K: Yes, we started calling out Ah ma! Ah ma! on the second-floor landing. But the moment we stepped into the smoke, I immediately started coughing. We had to retreat downstairs to catch our breath.W: At this point some people might ask - why didnt we just leave it to the firefighters who were about to arrive to rescue the Ah Ma? But it just didnt feel right to not do anything, especially when you know you can do something about it. Every minute felt precious.K: Yes, we felt like we had to die-die (absolutely) find Ah Ma.(Continued)

[ : - ] The Anti-Scam Division we know today has been expanded to form the Anti-Scam Command on 22 March 2022! With greater oversight over all scam-related investigations within the SPF and co-located industry partners, the command will focus on upstream interventions through close-knit collaboration with key partners and institutions in our continuous fight against scams. PoliceWPS2022PolicingwithaHeart

Rain or shine, the work of safeguarding Singapore never stops. We hope everyone is safe and sheltered. Have a good week ahead!Photo by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeverydaysaferneighbourhoodsinsg

The Police Psychological Services Department (PPSD) was formed in April 2021 to further develop the psychological competence of the Singapore Police Force (SPF), to enhance its operational and organisational effectiveness.Police psychologists like Mr Mohamad Zailan Salihin Bin Zaihan, conduct research in scams and crimes to help SPF officers better understand the modus operandi of the criminals and psyche of the victims, so as to develop effective victim-oriented crime prevention and care initiatives.In addition, Mr Zailan also conducts psychological training for SPF officers and provides operational support during crisis negotiation situations.

ASP Shasha (S): I remembered a light drizzle had just stopped on the night of 30 July 2021. Poh and I were driving around the Woodlands industrial area when we noticed a man in a Grab rider uniform standing at the roadside pavement. He appeared to be in pain and kept pointing to his ribcage area. We quickly parked our car to check on him. Strangely, he couldnt seem to respond properly to our questions. Thats when we learned he had a hearing disability. SSS Poh (P): We ended up communicating by typing out text messages on the phone. I remember the first thing I typed was are you injured? We learned that he was cycling while delivering food, but lost control and fell. He had some abrasions on his elbows and legs, so we asked him to lie down as we rendered some light first aid.S: Poh is the kind of officer who likes to bao ka liao (does everything) We also made a check with POCC to review the footage of the nearby PolCam to ensure he wasnt a victim of any hit-and-run accident. P: We were concerned that he might have suffered internal injuries, so we called for an ambulance. The man then gestured towards his bag to say that he still had to complete his food delivery order! I gave a call to Grab and explained the situation to them. I also gave a call to the mans next-of-kin and assured them that hes safe and will be brought to the nearby hospital. S: Then we realised - what do we do with his bicycle and the delivery? So we kept the bicycle safely locked and left a note to ensure it wouldnt be taken away. Unfortunately, we had to dispose of the food order. The ambulance soon came. After explaining to the paramedics, we bade him a safe farewell. P: A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to SC/CPL Xie Sibin, who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. S: It was nice and Im thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we dont do this just because were on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain or at loss its only human for us to offer help!mydutymycalling singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

P: A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to SC/CPL Xie Sibin, who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. S: It was nice and Im thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we dont do this just because were on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain or at loss its only human for us to offer help!mydutymycalling singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

ASP Shasha (S): I remembered a light drizzle had just stopped on the night of 30 July 2021. Poh and I were driving around the Woodlands industrial area when we noticed a man in a Grab rider uniform standing at the roadside pavement. He appeared to be in pain and kept pointing to his ribcage area. We quickly parked our car to check on him. Strangely, he couldnt seem to respond properly to our questions. Thats when we learned he had a hearing disability. SSS Poh (P): We ended up communicating by typing out text messages on the phone. I remember the first thing I typed was are you injured? We learned that he was cycling while delivering food, but lost control and fell. He had some abrasions on his elbows and legs, so we asked him to lie down as we rendered some light first aid.S: Poh is the kind of officer who likes to bao ka liao (does everything) We also made a check with POCC to review the footage of the nearby PolCam to ensure he wasnt a victim of any hit-and-run accident. P: We were concerned that he might have suffered internal injuries, so we called for an ambulance. The man then gestured towards his bag to say that he still had to complete his food delivery order! I gave a call to Grab and explained the situation to them. I also gave a call to the mans next-of-kin and assured them that hes safe and will be brought to the nearby hospital. S: Then we realised - what do we do with his bicycle and the delivery? So we kept the bicycle safely locked and left a note to ensure it wouldnt be taken away. Unfortunately, we had to dispose of the food order. The ambulance soon came. After explaining to the paramedics, we bade him a safe farewell. P: A few days later, we learned that the man had turned up at the NPC to pass us a handwritten note personally addressed to SC/CPL Xie Sibin, who had also assisted us in attending to the man that day. It was quite heartwarming. S: It was nice and Im thankful for having a good team. Though I have to say that we dont do this just because were on duty. When we see someone in need, in pain or at loss its only human for us to offer help!mydutymycalling singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

, : -Being a police officer makes me feel as though Im always in uniform. Like Im in a state of mind where Im constantly being vigilant. I think its a good thing.That day on 27 Feb 2021, my two friends and I were at the hotel swimming pool celebrating one of our birthdays. I noticed a few kids were playing at the other end of the pool with the adults. I have a young nephew at home, so I tend to be more aware when kids are involved. I then noticed at the corner of my eye something pink at the bottom of the pool. I waded closer and it only dawned on me when I saw a little girls motionless arms and legs. Without second thoughts, I dived into the pool to reach out to the girl, and one of the adults helped pull her out of the water. As the family members dialled for an ambulance, I attempted to do CPR on her. I remembered myself shaking when doing the compressions but I quickly composed myself as I had to stay absolutely focused on the task. To my relief, she eventually expelled out the water from her mouth and started breathing. The CPR compressions only lasted a minute but that moment felt like a whole millennia to me and her family members.The ambulance arrived shortly to bring the girl to the hospital. After everyone left, I decided to stay and sit on the bench near the swimming pool alone. I found myself thinking what could have happened if the girl didnt make it or if shell be okay. It was a mixture of relief and concern.When this incident was published on social media, the mother reached out to me. She expressed her thanks and said that her girl wanted to give me a token of gratitude. I appreciated the gesture but turned down her kind offer as I was just happy to hear that her daughter was safe and sound. Thats all I really needed.Im thankful for doing the things I get to do on a daily basis as an officer, to be able to make a difference in someones life with my little contributions. Honestly, I think anyone would have done what I did. All it takes is some courage something I believe everyone has in them.mydutymycallingsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Today is Total Defence Day.All of us play important roles in building a strong, secure and cohesive nation. Here are what Sergeant (V) Chua Cai Yun Yvonne and National Service Probationary Inspector (NSPI) Muhammad Irsyad Bin Abdul Jalil have to say about Total Defence.SGT (V) Yvonne Chua: "Always stay alert and be vigilant about your surroundings. Even though Singapore is very safe, things can always happen when you least expect it.NSPI Muhammad Irsyad Bin Abdul Jalil: "My officers and I are armed with mid-range firearms with higher firepower during deployments, in readiness to respond to public security-related and counter-terrorism incidents. During major security events, we will work tirelessly to ensure the safety and security of the events.WeAreTotalDefencesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Polices Neighbourhood Watch ZoneThe Neighbourhood Watch Scheme (NWS) was one of the SPFs first community crime prevention initiatives. It was launched in 1981 to encourage neighbours in public housing estates to band together as Neighbourhood Watch Groups (NWGs) and look out for each others person and property.Since 1997, NWGs have been reorganised into Neighbourhood Watch Zones (NWZs) formed under the Residents Committees (RCs) or Neighbourhood Committees (NCs) of the respective zones. All residents belonging to the particular RC/ NCs zone automatically become members of the NWZ, which works with their local Neighbourhood Police Centre to fight crime.A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details!--tuesdayssaferneighbourhoodsinsgsgpolicevolunteersSPFCommunityWatchSchemeSPFOurActionsCountFind out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)--Photo: A 1987 crime prevention poster encouraging residents participation in NWGs.

Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Polices Riders on Watch (ROW)Since 2019, our community volunteers under the Riders on Watch (ROW) scheme have partnered our Public Transport Security Command (TransCom) officers in their fight against crime on public transport services. ROW volunteers act as additional eyes and ears for TransCom during their commute on public transport nodes, by keeping watch for suspicious persons or activities and providing valuable information to the Police when needed. We thank all our volunteers for keeping our public transport networks safe!A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details!--tuesdayssaferneighbourhoodsinsgsgpolicevolunteersSPFCommunityWatchSchemeSPFOurActionsCountFind out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)--Photo: An ROW post card.

Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Polices Vehicles on Watch (VOW)You may have noticed these signages on Vehicles on Watch (VOW) at your local carparks. Since 2015, the SPF has called upon residents who own in-vehicle cameras to keep the vehicles in their neighbourhood safe. Participating residents under the VOW assist the Police in investigations by providing footage from their in-vehicle cameras. VOW car parks are identified by a sign installed at the car park entrance. Lets continue to keep our carparks safe!A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year, and this watch group will come under the new programme. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook page for more details!--tuesdayssaferneighbourhoodsinsgsgpolicevolunteersSPFCommunityWatchSchemeSPFOurActionsCountFind out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio) --Photo: A VOW sign by a Neighbourhood Police Centre.

Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Citizens on Patrol (COP) MemberThe Citizens on Patrol (COP) volunteer scheme was launched in 1999 to engage the community to patrol their neighbourhoods, alert the police to suspicious activities or characters, and share crime prevention knowledge with residents. Since 2019, COP members have been issued a standard vest and COP identification card while on patrol.COP members have been valuable partners to the SPF over the years, and their vigilance have enabled crimes such as thefts and loanshark activities, to be solved. We salute our COP volunteers for keeping their neighbourhoods safe!Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer: out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook!--Photo: COP members sharing crime prevention knowledge with residents.

Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Volunteer Special Constabulary (Community) OfficerThe Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC) (Community) vocation was launched in 2018 to create more opportunities for the public to join the VSC programme. The vocation has a shorter training duration and officers are required to perform unarmed police duties. VSC (Community) officers will be posted to one of the 7 Police Land Divisions or selected specialist and line units, and are required to serve a minimum of 8 hours of duty per month.Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer: out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. Keep a lookout for announcements on SPF Facebook!--Photo: VSC (Community) officers sharing crime prevention advisories with residents. (Source: Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.)

Police Heritage Story Volunteering with Police as a Volunteer Special Constabulary Officer2021 marks the 75th anniversary of the Volunteer Special Constabulary (VSC), which was formed in 1946 to augment the regular ranks in the Singapore Police Force (SPF). In the aftermath of World War II, manpower was badly needed to restore law and order in Singapore. About 100 men responded to the call and joined as the first VSC officers. Since then, thousands have followed in their footsteps and the VSC stands at more than 1,200 strong today.VSC officers are vested with the powers of a police officer and contribute significantly to keeping Singapore safe. We salute all VSC officers, past and present, for their service!Sign up at this link if you are interested to volunteer as a VSC: out what other exciting opportunity awaits when you volunteer with the Police today: (Link in bio)Hint: A new community volunteer programme will be launched in December this year. The VSC scheme was introduced on 1 October 1946 to augment the regular ranks in the Singapore Police Force (SPF) after World War II, when manpower was badly needed to restore law and order in Singapore.Throughout the years, VSC officers played an integral role serving alongside their regular and PNS counterparts in preventing, deterring and detecting crime.We thank all volunteers, past and present, for your contributions in keeping Singapore safe and secure.If you are interested in finding out more about the different volunteer schemes, click on the link in bio.safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforcesgpolicevolunteers

This is not a futuristic phone booth but SPF's very own Police Beacon! The Police Beacon was deployed at Punggol Waterway Park Connector and Sengkang Riverside Park Connector for trial in December 2020. Its built-in functions allow the public to connect with the Police directly in times of need and enhances security in secluded spaces.Have you seen or used the Police Beacon before? Share your experience with us below!Have a great weekend everyone!Photo by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydaysaferneighbourhoodsinsg

Some of you may have heard that one of our Gurkha Contingent (GC) officers, Subas Gurung, will be participating in the Pocari Sweat Run on 10 Oct 2021.The Singapore Police Force supports officers like Subas, who train hard every day to keep operationally fit, in order to safeguard Singapore and her residents. Subas is known to be one of the fittest officers in the GC. He last recorded a 6 minutes 58 seconds timing for his 2.4km run during his IPPT in July 2021, after doing 59 push-ups and 60 sit-ups, finishing with a perfect score.As an avid runner, Subas registered for the run on 3 Sep 2021 on his own accord, and is looking to join the race not to best any runner, but merely to challenge himself and his personal record. He is but one of the many GC officers who push themselves to their limit on a regular basis, training hard so that they can execute demanding duties well in a variety of police operations.The Singapore Police Force is proud to have officers like Subas. Whatever the results may be on 10 Oct 2021, it is the spirit of sportsmanship, steadfastness and service to the nation which Subas embodies, that matters most.We will cheer for Subas as well as the many other participating runners from all walks of life at the upcoming run!SingaporePoliceForce SafeguardingEverydayPhoto 1: GC officer Subas Gurung (centre) representing SPF in the World Police & Fire Games in 2019Photo 2: Gurkha Contingent officers are deployed for a variety of operational roles, for example, to ensure security at the recent visit to Singapore by the Vice President of the United States (22-24 August 2021).
