In the first half of 2021, loan scams became the top scam type while the number of job scam cases reported jumped more than sixteen-fold compared to the same period in 2020.Principal Psychologist Ms Carolyn Misir from the Police Psychological Services Department shared how scammers tend to take advantage of prevailing societal conditions and change their tactics accordingly, using a variety of persuasion techniques and cognitive biases to induce victims into falling prey to scams.Fighting scams is a community effort. Beware of scams and stay well-informed! Your vigilance is our very first line of defence.spotthesignssingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

While scams remain a concern, the Police have been doubling efforts in the fight against scams through various initiatives with multiple stakeholders.Deputy Assistant Commissioner of Police Aileen Yap from the Anti-Scam Division shared the latest initiative, Project COMBAT, which utilises Robotic Process Automation to send out targeted advisories to warn potential scam victims from falling prey. This will be scalable to address new scam trends as they continue to evolve.The Police will continue to work closely with both local telcos and foreign law enforcement agencies to share information on emerging scams and cripple scam syndicates.spotthesignssingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Happy Friday! Our Special Operations Command (SOC) officers are ever-ready to leap into action. Time to soar into the weekend!Photo by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday saferneighbourhoodsinsg

<Post-Blast Investigations Finding the needle in the haystack quickly>At the post-blast scene, things can be pretty messy and uncovering the truth after an explosion can be daunting.Enter the post-blast investigators, who seek to gather and process leads quickly to identify potential culprits and stop them from causing further harm to innocent victims. All these have to be done while ensuring that the crime scene is not contaminated and that their safety are not compromised.Here are some photos showing what the investigators need to do at a post-blast scene.Photo 1: A mock-up scene after a bomb blast.Photo 2: Investigators have to don the full protective gear to protect themselves from corrosive chemicals or infectious substances, and to prevent contamination of the scene.Here, he is picking up traces of explosive substances left at the scene and analysing them using the Explosives Test Kit.This kit helps detect a wide spectrum of explosive substances or trace residues present at the scene.Photo 3: Investigator gathering traces of explosive substances and analysing them using a chemical analyser.This machine measures the amount of light energy absorbed or scattered by the unknown chemical after being excited by a laser. It is used to identify unknown chemicals both in solid and liquid forms in post-blast investigation operations.Photo 4: Investigator performing X-ray on an object suspected to be a component of an improvised explosive device using the portable X-ray system.The portable X-ray system is used to ascertain the internal contents of an object, and to determine if it is safe for the investigator to process the object.

Happy Friday! Seen the VIPs Motorcade at the ceremonial parade on National Day? Heres some fun facts about it:The motorcade is a display of precision, teamwork and trust between the officers. Five Traffic Police riders and the VIPs vehicle enter the Float, travel and stop at precisely the same speed. Thereafter, in a well-trained and coordinated manner, all the riders place their left legs down at the exact same time once their vehicles come to a stop. Be sure to keep a lookout for this in the next NDP show! Have a good weekend!safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforceNDP2021TogetherOurSGSpirit

We hope you have caught the Ceremonial Parade earlier this morning. DSP Gregory Kang is the commander for the SPF Guard of Honour contingent this year, and here is what he has to say!Our Singapore Spirit is an enduring one, where many generations have worked hard in our nation building journey and passed the baton to the next generation.Every year, the National Day reminds us of how far this country has gone against the odds, and how the men and women of the Singapore Police Force will continue to play our part to keep the Singapore flag flying high, by keeping our people safe and secure.safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforceNDP2021TogetherOurSGSpirit

Our nations road to independence and early years were fraught with challenges, but our pioneers stood firm in adversity and overcame all odds, to build the country we call home today. We have our own set of challenges today, but with unity, resilience and determination, we will ride out the storm together. Happy birthday, Singapore! Here are some photos of the Singapore Police Force contingents participating in the Parade segment on National Day over the years since independence. [ : , ]When it comes to operational duties, time is of the essence.The Automated Equipping System (AES) allows officers to withdraw and return operational equipment from smart lockers complemented by RFID and QR code technology at the start and end of their shift. This automated process removes the need for a maintenance officer thus saving time and improving efficiency at work.From 2021, an updated AES with improved design and specifications will be rolled out to all NPCs progressively.PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

[ : , ]Mimicking an operational terrain and driven by analytics, the Live Instrumentation Training System (LITS) comprises of an Instrumented Laser Engagement System and a Force-On-Robotic Target, which uses a human-like target system with a shoot-back system that can identify, track and fire at trainees.The analytics system then consolidates results of the simulated firefight and provides training data such as the number of shots hit or missed, time taken and location. This feedback allows trainees to take prompt corrective action, thus improving overall training efficacy and enhances training realism.From December 2021, the SPF, HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) and Home Team Academy (HTA) will trial LITS with frontline officers who are undergoing In-Situ Reaction Team tactical training for a 3-month period at HTA. Should the trial be successful, frontline officers can look forward to the implementation of LITS for tactical training in the future.PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

The Police would like to alert members of the public to stay vigilant against job scams. These scams may come in the form of text messages and would typically offer highly-paid job openings that can be performed from home.Learn how to spotthesigns and share this message with your family and friends.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

[SPF Workplan Seminar 2021: Smarter Policing, Empowered Community]The Mobile TASER Training Target (MTTT) uses computer vision technology to detect the landing points of taser probes on the training target, and collect training data to analyse trainees strengths and weaknesses in their deployment of the taser.This helps officers in their post-training evaluation to sharpen and enhance taser training.MTTT reduces the risk of injury during scenario-based training and is especially useful during the COVID-19 pandemic in reducing physical contact during training.From July 2021, the SPF and HTX (Home Team Science and Technology Agency) will trial customised prototypes of the MTTT with SPF frontline units for a 3-month period. Should the trial be successful, frontline officers can look forward to the implementation of MTTT for training in the future.PoliceWPS2021SmarterPolicingEmpoweredCommunity

Doesnt he look familiar? Yes! He was the Ground Response Force Team Leader in our recent video titled Our People, Our Heartware, published on Police Day! In case you are wondering, he is indeed a police officer (and not an actor)!SUPT Shannon Lin is currently the Deputy Head of the Unlicensed Moneylending Strikeforce under the Criminal Investigation Department. At work, he leads a team of officers in solving crimes related to unlicensed moneylending.At home, he is a proud father of two lovely kids, Shania and Shane.I am proud of papa, because he catches bad guys to keep us safe, said Shania. Shania, Shannon's 6-year-old daughter, inspired by her father, wishes to become a scientist one day so that she can "make medicine to save lives just like papa".I just hope that she can grow up to be a compassionate person, said Shannon in response to the impact he wishes to leave on his daughter.Its safe to say that his hope is turning into a reality.Happy Fathers Day to all fathers who continue to inspire and motivate our next generation!Photos by: Naveen Rajsingaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday happyfathersday

There is no such thing as a "Government subsidised loan package."A licensed moneylender cannot advertise loan services via cold calls or unsolicited text messages, or even on social media or online marketplace platforms. If you receive a cold call, unsolicited text message, or see a Facebook ad asking if you would like to take up a loan, please do not respond. Block and report the number to the Police via the i-witness platform.Do also share this advisory with your family and friends.

Making illegal soccer bets online contravenes the Remote Gambling Act. Under the Act, anyone caught using remote communications and using a remote gambling service by a non-exempted operator can get fined up to $5,000, or jailed up to 6 months, or both. If you receive such SMSes, you can either provide the information to us via our i-Witness portal or call the Police Hotline at 1800-255-0000. Let's enjoy the European Football Championship and not get too carried away in the excitement!safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce euro2020

Before Singapore gained full internal self-governance in 1959, the Police crest was adapted from the colonial flag and comprised an inverted pall with a crown in the middle, representing the Crown Colony of Singapore. After 1959, Singapores state flag, comprising a crescent moon and five stars,was adapted into the Police crest which we recognise today. Look out for a genuine 1950s Police cap badge and more in the Frontier Town to Safest City virtual exhibition. Click the link in bio to begin your journey!(Image of Colonial Singapore Police Force cap badge courtesy of private collector) SingaporePoliceHeritagePoliceVirtualTour

Police Day has been observed every 3 June since 1971. A date of special significance, 3 June 1959 was when Singapore obtained self-governance and the Police became the law enforcement agency of an elected Government. Although Police Day will be observed differently this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, SPF officers remain unwavering in their pledge to serve the nation and carry out their duties with courage, loyalty, integrity and fairness.singaporepoliceheritage policeday2021 ---If you enjoyed this post and want to learn more about SPFs history, we invite you to visit the Frontier Town to Safest City virtual tour (see link @ bio)!---Picture 1: Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Wong Lin Ken, at the first Police Day parade in 1971. (Source: Ministry of Information and the Arts Collection, courtesy of National Archives of Singapore)Picture 2: Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr S. Jayakumar at 1993 Police Day parade.Picture 3: Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr K Shanmugam at 2019 Police Day parade

Growing up, Sergeant Leow Su Ling watched her mother served in the Singapore Police Force (SPF) with both dedication and passion. This became a valuable inspiration and motivating factor for her to join the force, with a trusted confidante and adviser by her side through life and work.Mdm Ng Lay Hong, who joined the SPF in 1981 and retired in 2018 with the rank of Senior Station Inspector, is a proud mother of two children. She constantly reminds her daughter, Su Ling to stay humble and kind to others despite the challenges faced daily. When asked what Motherhood meant to her, she said, Being a Mother is one of the most powerful experiences that has brought a deeper meaning to my life. The days are long and you dont really get a day off from being a mother, but it gives me immense joy knowing that Ive raised two children who are contributing back to society in their own ways.Happy Mothers Day to all the wonderful and noble mothers out there!Photo by: SC Aloysious Lowsingaporepoliceforce happymothersday

<Safety is Polices top priority in stand-off situations>Stand-off situations are incidents where Police are alerted after individuals locked themselves up to evade arrest or attempt suicide.Polices priority in such stand-off situations is to ensure safety of all persons involved and to resolve the situation with minimal harm to persons and property.Various Police resources such as the Ground Response Force (GRF), Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU), Special Operations Command (SOC) are deployed to provide tactical options to deal with unpredictable circumstances.Given the high volatility of such situations, there exist great operational risks to our officers and officers do get hurt at times.When the individual involved has been restrained, the Police will also consider the condition of the individual and convey him/her to the hospital/Institute of Mental Health immediately, after assessing if they require medical assistance or treatment.Here are some photos of the re-enactment illustrating how Police deal with such situations.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Did you know? The building we know today as Maxwell Chambers Suites was the former Traffic Police Headquarters for 69 years from 1930 to 1999. The building housed both offices and barracks facilities for officers and their families. It was also the site of Singapores first Driving Test Centre when driving tests were first introduced in 1941.Go on an adventure this weekend and discover nine iconic Police landmarks that played a role in safeguarding Singapore in the past! Photo: Man acquiring a driving licence from the Driving Test Centre at the Traffic Police Headquarters, 1951. (Source: Ministry of Information and the Arts Collection, courtesy of )ExplorePoliceHeritageTrailsingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

Recognised for their impressive strength, intelligence and sense of smell, dogs have been working alongside our officers since 1955. Not all dog breeds are suited for police work, and they are carefully selected and trained for tasks ranging from tracking criminals to detecting explosives. The first police dog in the SPF was a German Shepard named Rover, who was brought over from the UK in 1955 by his handler Chief Inspector Frank Pestana to form the nucleus of the K9 Unit. Picture: Chief Inspector Frank Pestana training with Police Dog Rover, circa. 1955.OurSPF200Heritagesafeguardingeveryday

The Singapore Police Force Scholarship (SPFS) is one of the most prestigious scholarship awarded by the Public Service Commission. Meet our Singapore Police Force Scholarship scholars, Inspector Sundaram Mohan Shakthi and Inspector Sim Zheng Hao! Both of them were awarded the scholarship earlier today. Inspector Sundaram Mohan Shakthi is our second female recipient of the SPFS. When she was just 16-year-old, she learnt that the SPF is not about just catching and punishing criminals. It also focuses on rehabilitating offenders and providing social support to their family members. When asked why he wanted to join the SPF, Inspector Sim Zheng Hao said that he had a deep-rooted interest in a SPF career. His father, a former police officer, shared encounters from his policing days in 1980s since he was a child. Inspector Sim now wants to continue helping the community and give back to the society. The Singapore Police Force (SPF) Scholarship & Home Team (HT) Scholarship Award Ceremony was held virtually on Thursday, 20 August 2020. Find out more about our other scholars on SPF Facebook (link in bio).singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

The Singapore Police Force commemorates Police Day on 3 June every year, since 1971. 3 June 1959 is a date of special significance as Singapore obtained self-governance on that day.In 1971, Professor Wong Lin Ken, then Minister for Home Affairs, announced the designation of 3 June as Police Day. In his speech at the opening of Police Week on 3 June 1971, he said, The Government has designated 3rd of June to be Police Day, to reaffirm the fact that the Police is a part of our society, responsible to an elected government, and the maintenance of law and order is a service to the community. This photo was taken during the first Police Day Parade on 3 June 1971. : Courtesy of National Archives of Singaporesingaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeveryday

OurSPF200Heritage thursday Reserve Unit officers used water jets to disperse crowds in the Hock Lee bus riots that took place in 1955. The riots claimed the lives of two police officers, a news correspondent, and a 16-year old student who was paraded by the rioters for hours after sustaining a gunshot wound. Lets treasure what we have in Singapore today. : Ministry of Information and the Arts Collection, courtesy of (Colourised result of picture is generated by Colourise.sg.)

From using scavenged equipment left behind from World War II, the SPF has come a long way in developing its radio communication capabilities. With the integration of new technologies and processes, the SPFs command and control coordination and capabilities have evolved tremendously! Swipe left to see the changes from 1940s to 1950s to 2000s till today. The SPF have come a long way, from a 12-man team formed in May 1820, to a force of more than 15,000 officers today.You can visit the SPF200 exhibition at and witness our evolution over the two centuries! The exhibition is open now till 17 May this year.singaporepoliceforcesafeguardingeverydaySPF200

Today marks the opening of the SPF200 Exhibition - Frontier Town to Safest City which was officiated by Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law. The exhibition is part of a year-long series of events to commemorate SPF200 with 2020 being the 200th year of policing in Singapore. The exhibition brings visitors through the Polices 200-year policing journey using stories of how its officers exhibited bravery in the face of danger, of bringing criminals to justice, and of duty above self. The exhibition also showcases a collection of archival photos, videos and artefacts, some of which date all the way back to 1821.The exhibition at the will run from 6 February to 17 May 2020. Come visit the exhibition today! Free admission for all. Sign up for guided tours by our ex-Police officers who will share their exciting stories with SPF while you walk down the memory lane with them!singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday spf200

Introducing the team of SPF officers that conceptualised the Anti-Scam Centre (aka ASC). The ASC focuses on disrupting scammers operations to mitigate victims monetary losses. Particularly, it works closely with the three major local banks DBS Bank, OCBC Bank and UOB, to swiftly freeze suspicious bank accounts which are detected to be involved in scammers operations, and impede fund transfers involving such accounts. Meet our very first female recipient of the Singapore Police Force Scholarship awarded by the Public Service Commission, Inspector Shermaine Ang! She shared that as she was growing up, she noticed how the community benefitted from swift and timely interventions by police officers. It made her see how the SPF is a community-facing organisation whose work makes a real impact on the everyday lives of Singaporeans. It is a privilege and joy to work together with like-minded Singaporeans who believe in giving their best to protect and secure our home. she said. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

SCCPL Wong Yew Kit is one of the Police National Servicemen (NSFs) who were presented with the NSF of the Year Award. His core duty is to provide photography coverage for various SPF-related events and operations and the photos are used in various SPF internal and public communication materials to showcase policing work. Pssst do you know that some of the action-packed photos youve seen here on our Instagram are taken by him? Visit the link in our bio and Insta-story to find out which other PNSFs received this prestigious award too!

Seen them around in your daily commute? Yes, they are our officers from the Police Transport Command (TransCom)! The basic unit of TransComs frontline patrol resources is the Foot Patrol Group. One of their main tasks is to conduct high visibility foot patrols within the MRT system (i.e. MRT stations and trains) to detect and deter crime, including terrorism. They are often the first to respond to incidents reported in the public transport system.safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce

We have SSI(V) Hapit Osman, a VSC officer attached to the Traffic Police. He will be part of the mobile column drive-past at the parade. We also have ASP(V) Paul Seah Ching San, Deputy Head of the Recruitment Unit at VSC HQ, who is the reserve Contingent Commander for SAF - Home Team Volunteer Contingent. Find this familiar? Yes, it is a snapshot of the Cairnhill Neighbourhood Police Post which first opened its doors in 1989! Introduced in 1983, the Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) system was inspired by the Japanese Koban-style of policing and it helped to reduce crime rates in the neighbourhood. In 1997, the first Neighbourhood Police Centres (NPCs) were introduced. Fine-tuned from the NPP system, NPCs were bigger in size and scope of duties. Lets continue to work together to keep our neighbourhoods safe and crime-free. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
Ending the week beautifully. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

The Police works closely with community partners in Singapore to enhance their emergency preparedness and security measures against security threats. This is especially important in a hospital setting, where hospital staff play key roles to ensure the safety and security of their patients, who may be unable to run or hide on their own due to existing medical conditions. A counter-terrorism exercise codenamed Heartbeat was held at The Ang Mo Kio-Thye Hua Kwan Hospital today. The exercise was jointly organised by the Police and Thye Hua Kwan Moral Society, supported by the SCDF. This is the first time Exercise Heartbeat was held in a community hospital in Singapore, which reflects how community partners had taken ownership of their safety and security. More deets about what happened in bio and Insta-story! singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

In an emergency, their mission is to stop assailants and prevent the loss of innocent lives. The father-son duo, Station Inspector (SI) Mohamad Kamal and Assistant Superintendent (ASP) Mohamad Fazlin, have served the Singapore Police Force (SPF) for the last five years together. SI Kamal is a veteran officer who has gone on five United Nations (UN) missions as part of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force (UNPKF) between 1993 and 2008, and is now a Chief Musician in the SPF Band. ASP Fazlin currently leads a team of Ground Response Force officers in Geylang NPC. ASP Fazlin reminisced fondly about his childhood and how his father has influenced him. Read what the father and son have to say to each other on this Fathers Day on SPF FB (Link on bio). We wish all fathers a Happy Fathers Day! safeguardingeveryday fathersday2019

On 25 March 2019 at about 7.40pm, in a joint operation with the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority, PCG detected an unnumbered fiberglass boat at the sea off Punggol Barat, Singapore. The boat then entered Singapore territorial waters and sped towards the shore of Punggol Barat. The boatman refused to stop his boat despite repeated verbal and visual warnings through firing of flares by the PCG. PCG then swiftly intercepted the boat and arrested the 46-year-old boatman. A 20-year-old man was subsequently arrested at the fencing along the coastline of Punggol Barat.The motorized fiberglass boat and cash amounting to RM$3,734 were seized.Preliminary investigations revealed that the Malaysian boatman had picked up the Bangladeshi man from the shoreline of Johor Bahru, Malaysia. Both men were arrested for entering Singapore unlawfully under the Immigration Act, Chapter 133.The boatman is also being investigated for engaging in the business or trade of conveying illegal immigrant to Singapore under Section 57(1)(c) of the Immigration Act, Chapter 133. safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce

Superintendent of Police Sng May Yen was the first woman to assume the role of Singapore Contingent Commander of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force (UNPKF). She led the Singapore Contingent to East Timor twice, once in 2007 and another in 2010. Link to video of her story in bio.

ICYMI SPF celebrated its 70th anniversary of recruiting female officers last Saturday. What started out as an "experiment" in 1949 was a success as women showed great aptitude for policing. Today, our female officers are trained to the same standards as their male counterparts and serve in diverse roles within the Force. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Today, the Singapore Police Force celebrates 70 years of women in the force. DSP Ho Li Fang and DSP Ong Ruo Cheng are just two of the many women in the force who never let their gender stop them from achieving their goals. Taking part in the planning of large scale security events in Singapore, they credit the success to their team where both male and female officers work together, equally hard! womeninpolicing safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce

The road traffic situation in 2018 remained stable. There were fewer road traffic accidents overall, but the number of fatal accidents increased slightly. While there were fewer speeding violations and related accidents, there was an increase in the number of red-light running violations and related accidents, as well as drink-driving related accidents. Elderly pedestrians and motorcyclists continue to be of concern.singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday taketheroadtoresponsibility

Woof woof! I am Gerry, a seven-year-old German Shepherd, trained as a Police Patrol Dog. Like the rain drops that have fallen on my fur, I feel my eyes watering as I think about my retirement in five months time. But no, I held it back as I am now on a mission with my dog handler, Station Inspector (SI) Yap Hong Lee. We are patrolling hand and paw together to protect the 33rd ASEAN Summit against public security and public order threats. SI Yap has been my handler since I joined the Force. Theres an indescribable bond between us as we have weathered uncountable days of rain and shine together. This may be my last major security deployment, but once a police dog, always a police dog! I will always remember my patrol moments with SI Yap. He is the best handler that a dog could have. For now, it is back to my duty to support my handler in his mission to safeguard the summit! Woof! Gerry

Ms ChianhJia Xuan hasalways wanted to play a part in keeping Singapore safe as she strongly believes that the security climate of our nation determines the happiness of our people. Thus, serving with the force will allow her to contribute actively in maintaining the peace of the country and ensuring the safety of Singaporeans. Ms Chianhbegan volunteering with the Voluntary Special Constabulary since July last year and observed the rigour and tenacity required for the job.It is through this volunteering stint that Ms Chianh realized serving with the SPF is the career path for her as she looked forward to waking up to a challenging yet meaningful task every day. By majoring in psychology, she hopes to be able to contribute toa resilient culture in the force by preparing police officers for future challenges and sustaining their passion for the force.Congratulations to Ms Chianh for being one of the Local Merit Scholarship recipients at the Singapore Police Force Scholarship and Home Team Scholarship Award Ceremony 2018! Good job! singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Police NSF Hazim had no thoughts at all of joining the Singapore Police Force prior to his National Service (NS) stint. However, that changed after he met Senior Staff Sergeant (SSSgt) Aziz, his Course Manager at Training Command, and began his NS experience with the In-Situ Reaction Team of Protective Security Command (ProCom).His stint has exposed him to the wider roles that the Singapore Police Force plays in keeping the nation safe, especially so in ProCom where the responsibility stretches to counter-terrorism work and keeping key installations secure. The distinct spirit present in his team in a time where the security climate is uncertain further solidifies his decision to serve with the force. Hazim hopes that he can be posted back to ProCom one day so that he would be able to share and inspire other PNSFs on the work of the Singapore Police Force, just like his mentor SSSGT Aziz did. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

Station Inspector Syed Abu Bakar, a trained emergency medical technician, was involved in the rescue of passengers from a ferry which ran aground near Pulau Tekong on Monday night. The first thing that ran through his mind was to find out the extent of the victims injuries, so that he can prioritise the emergency care needed, and plan evacuation. The terrain added on to the difficulty of the rescue. We are glad that they are now safe! DAC Zhang Weihan (left) will assume the Command of Ang Mo Kio Police Division on 3 November 2017. As part of NS50 celebrations, the Old Police Academy (OPA) has re-opened its gates one last time for all retired and serving Police National Servicemen and their families today. While OPA was the official training ground for Police officers from 1929 till 2005, it also served as a venue for many community events that had helped to forge closer bonds between the Police and the public. DSP Tan Boon Heng was recognised for his 40 years of service at the SPF Service Medals Presentation Ceremony 2016 held last week. After joining the force as a Police Constable in 1972, DSP Tan rose through the ranks. He is currently the Commanding Officer of Ang Mo Kio South Neighbourhood Police Centre.Reflecting on his career, DSP Tan said, A challenging career with its highs and lows. As I reflect, I feel that it is a fulfilling career which have given me many memorable experiences. Together with DSP Tan, over 1000 officers were recognised for their good conduct and long service at the presentation ceremony.Thank you for your dedication to the force! :) SPFPridetbt

EXERCISE HEARTBEAT 2016 safeguardingeveryday Earlier today, the Police and SCDF conducted an exercise codenamed Exercise Heartbeat at the Esplanade-Theatres on the Bay. The threat of terror attacks in Singapore is at its highest in recent times. Exercise Heartbeat 2016 serves to enhance the emergency preparedness and resilience of the business community, so that they can better respond and cope in an actual terror attack.

MissingTypeSG A blood donation drive was held at the Police Headquarters today, 16 Aug 2016, in support of the International Missing Type Campaign launched by the Health Sciences Authority and Singapore Red Cross .SC Sgt Rayner Tay was one of the many officers who responded to the call to give blood and save lives. On how he felt, the first time donor said, I am happy to be participating in this meaningful event to make a difference by saving someone. To find out more about the MissingTypeSG campaign, go to redcross.sg/missingtype.

Crimewatch made its debut on 30 November 1986, showcasing the work of the Singapore Police Force. The first episode chalked up a viewership of 1.3 million, and prompted 37 viewers to call the Police to provide information on three unsolved murder cases that were featured! One of such tip-offs led to the arrest of 5 suspects who were involved in one of the murder cases.Thirty years on, Crimewatch is still the longest running docu-drama series and continues to attract the highest viewership on Channel 5. thursday singaporepoliceforce irememberspf singaporememoryproject

repost with Traffic Police officers Staff Sergeant Abdul Hakim (left) and Staff Sergeant Fadli Shaifuddin. They were offered but rejected bribes. I met them today, among 43 public officers and private individuals, to commend and congratulate them for their honesty and good work. Many other stories of Singaporeans combating corruption are on display at CPIBs roving exhibition Declassified: Corruption Matters, now on at the National Library till 22 May. Some cases are being made public for the first time in 64 years!We should never take Singapores clean system for granted. Grateful to the men and women whose honesty, integrity and resolve keep our country transparent and incorrupt. LHL (Photo courtesy of Abdul Hakim)

SAFEGUARDING SINGAPORES WATERS This afternoon, Minister for Home Affairs Mr K Shanmugam visited the Police Coast Guard (PCG) to observe PCGs counter-terrorism and maritime security measures. During the visit, Minister K Shanmugam was briefed on PCGs new capabilities which include enhanced surveillance systems. He also observed a live demonstration showcasing polices readiness when responding to hijack and hostage situations at sea. The visit ended off with a sea demonstration of PCGs latest fleet of vessels - the Patrol Interdiction Boats and 2nd Generation PK Interceptors. At the visit, Minister emphasized the importance of PCGs role in safeguarding our waters to ensure the safety and security of Singapore. safeguardingeverydaysingaporepoliceforce

On 27 November 2015, Deputy Team Leaders of the Courts Police Unit, Station Inspectors Quek Suan and Jahabar Sadiq performed Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) on a man who had collapsed in one of the court rooms and became unresponsive. After two rounds of chest compressions and mouth-to-mouth breathing, the man suddenly gasped for air and became responsive. He was subsequently sent to hospital where he made a full recovery.Recounted SI Quek, "As a police officer, it was instinctive for me to act." For their quick actions in administering first aid to the man, both Central Division officers were awarded the Survivor Awards Singapore yesterday. singaporepoliceforceSPFPride

Esplanade park. 10am. A "gunman" opens fire at members of public, leaving many "injured". Police officers quickly respond to subdue the "gunman" and arrest him. Be vigilant and report any suspicious activity or persons to the authorities.singaporepoliceforce

Manned by Radio Division personnel, the Radio Control Room was the centre of all Police communications. The Duty Officer Radio sat at the raised centre of this Control table. He was assisted by the Assistant Duty Officer and a number of operators seated at the individual pods around the table who handled 999 calls.This was fondly known by officers as the UFO! Keen to visit this UFO at the fCOR exhibition? Call 9893 5140 or email us at fcor.gov.sg to make a tour booking now! singaporepoliceforcesg50

The fCOR was the nerve centre where major crises that shaped current Singapore were managed and resolved. These include the 1956 Chinese Middle School Riots, Konfrontasi and the 1969 race riots. Here's a sneak peek into the fCOR exhibition! singaporepoliceforcesg50

Guest of Honour, Mr. Amrin Amin, Parliamentary Secretary, MHA together with one of our pioneer officers, Mr Michael De Whitt have officially launched the Former Combined Operations (fCOR) Exhibition. "While the fCOR has ceased operations in these premises for some 26 years, we are reminded of the dedication and contributions of our Pioneers in building a safe and secure Singapore."- Mr Amrin Amin singaporepoliceforcesg50

Take a walk down memory lane with us at the Police Heritage Centre this Jubilee Weekend!The Police Heritage Centre is opening its gallery from 7-10 August 2015. Visitors will get the chance to learn more about the Singapore Police Forces rich history through a 1.5 hour guided tour. The tours are conducted at the following timeslots daily: 10am, 11.30am, 2.30pm and 4pm. Hurry and book a visit by contacting us at 6478 2123 or spf_police_heritage.gov.sg. SG50 singaporepoliceforce jubileeweekend

Behind the precision and coordination of the NDP Guard of Honour Contingent stands a trainer. Every year, SSSgt Ridzuan Zakaria trains a fresh batch of recruits from zero to perfection. We start from scratch with every batch, teaching them the basic drills and arms drill, how to march and how to handle a SAR21. Once the trainees are familiar with the drills, we will move on to the parade sequence. It is hard work and we start training in April all the way to NDP. This year marks SSSgt Ridzuans 10th year in NDP as the Chief Trainer for the Police GOH!NDP2015 Singapore SG50 singaporepoliceforce

Did you know that we have a pair of non-identical twins in this years NDP Guard-of-Honour (GOH) Contingent? Officer Cadets Si Yuan (left) and Si Ern (right), both age 18, were excited to be selected to participate in NDP. Si Ern said, SG50 is a big milestone for Singapore and we are very honoured to be part of the celebration. We will definitely look back on this as a fond memory and we hope that in SG100, we can participate in the parade together again in our 70s! NDP2015 Singapore SG50 singaporepoliceforce

Meet SSI (V) Hapit Bin Osman, a 25-year veteran Volunteer Special Constabulary Patrol Officer with the Traffic Police. He is part of the Mobile Column for NDP 2015.
